DUAN NA BAINNSE

1 . Paibil :
anglicised Paible ; a general name for the district between the loch of the same name that adjoins Balranald ( made an arm of the sea shortly after MacCodrum ’ s death by a cutting called An Dìg Mhór ) and Bayhead
( Ceann a ’ Bhàigh ) .
It is the most populous district in Uist . The pronunciation in the eighteenth century , to judge from the rime with maduinn ( cf . also l . 617 ff . ) , differed from that of the present day — Peabail — and was the same as the present Lewis pronunciation of the same name ( but anglicised Bayble ) .

9 . an teine :
probably a fire built for the benefit of those guests entertained in the open .

11 . am muilleir :
the miller was perhaps the father of the bride in whose house the wedding festivities would take place . In 1792 there were three mills in the parish of North Uist ( Old Stat . Acc . , xiii , 304 , 313 ) . These were probably the same that are still standing , at Loch nan Geirean , Tigharry , and Dusary , of which the last named is the only one now in working order . Millers do not appear to have been popular in the eighteenth century . Private grinding was prohibited by a law of Alexander II , and millers were empowered to seek out querns and destroy them . A raid for this purpose was carried out in South Uist c . 1750 , when a large number of querns were thrown into the sea ( Clan Donald , iii , 130 ) .

17 . Domhnall mac Gille - Mhàrtuinn :
He was the bridegroom , who had to supply the whisky , and therefore did not welcome an addition to the original number of guests .

Gille - Màrtuinn is here aspirated in the genitive in both its component parts . But the second part was often not aspirated . Cf . l . 2858 which follows S . , and l . 2422 which follows M . In the North Uist Rental of 1718 both “ Mcillickallum ” and “ McGillechallum ” are to be found . In the same Rental one Annable McEan vic illimartin appears as one of the tenants of Balemore . The only other instance of the name is in Baile Mhic Phàil , where Killmartin Munro is a tenant ( Clan Donald , iii , 662 ) .
ORAN MU ’ N EIDEADH GHÀIDHEALACH

In T . the title is
“ Oran le Iain MacCodrum , agus e bhi diombach air son an eididh Ghaidhealaich thoirt uaithe , ’ n deigh bliadhna Thearlach . ”
In U . it is called
“ Oran a Rinn saighdear a bh ’ ann sa n , arm dhearg an am do na chasag a bhi aig arm an ( airm written above ) Righ ( Deors written above ) , ” which does not accord with the content of the song nor with the fact that soldiers were not prohibited from wearing the Highland dress . In EP . the heading is simply
“ An Aghaidh an Eididh Ghallda Le Iain MacCodrum , ”
and the same heading appears in GB . The song seems to have been widely known , and — no doubt as a consequence — the various versions differ considerably . T . , the earliest and fullest , is here followed , except where considerations such as metre and assonance and meaning have led to the adoption of readings from the later versions .

The song was composed when the Highland dress was proscribed after the rebellion of 1745 - 1746 . This was done by an act passed in 1746 called “ An Act for the more effectual disarming of the Highlands in Scotland ; and for the more effectually securing the Peace of the said Highlands ; and for restraining the Use of the Highland Dress … ( further provisions of the act ) . ” The clause relating to the Highland dress was to take effect from and after 1st August 1747 . The proscription applied only to Scotland and an exception was made in favour of “ Officers and Soldiers in his Majesty ’ s Forces ” ( 19 Geo . 2 , c . 17 ) . By an act of the following year , however , the enforcement of this clause , “ as to all those who are not landed Men , ” was postponed until 1st August 1748 ( 20 Geo . 2 , C . 51 ) . In 1748 a further postponement , “ as to the Plaid , Philibeg or Little Kilt ” until 25th December 1748 , and as regards the rest of the dress , until 1st August 1749 was enacted ( 21 Geo . 2 , c . 34 ) . MacCodrum ’ s song was composed probably not long after the former date .

Tha mi tursach tinn
Tha mi sgìth dochart ,
Ceangal air mo bhuill
Us cha dean mi coiseachd .
( Henderson ’ s Dàin Iain Ghobha , ii , 38 . )

63 . beul sìos :
common in the imprecation Beul sìos ort !
By one authority ( UB . , 105 ) connected with “ the tendency of the underlip — especially in children — hanging down when a person is in sorrow . ” The imprecation , however , is stronger than that , meaning “ Mayest thou fall down dead . ” The dead in battle would be found usually face downwards and such was the regular posture of death in the old tales ; cf . the English phrase “ to bite the dust . ” Cf . also An fhìrinn ’ sa beoil foipe sìos ( BGh . , l . 2342 n . ) ; Marbhphaisg ort !
( Death - shroud on thee ) ; Geòlach ort !
( Death - shoulder - bands on thee ) . It may be noted that according to one account Mary MacLeod gave orders on her death - bed that she should be buried face downwards as a punishment for having forgiven the chief who banished her and for having composed a song in his praise ( Henderson ’ s Dàin Iain Ghobha , 1 , xiv ) . Cf . the death of Airnélach mac Adhmalláin , son of the king of Leinster , as told to St Patrick by Caoilte : “ tuc a aigid re talmain 7 nir ’ thócaib a ghnúis nogu bhfuair bás do náire . ”
( Stokes and Windisch , Acallam na Senórach , Irische Texte , Fourth Series , i , ll . 1072 - 1073 . ) See also l . 1971 .

67 . an t - osan geàrr :
Taylor , the water poet , describing the dress of Highlanders in 1618 , says , “ Their habite is shooes with but one sole a - piece ; stockings ( which they call short hose ) made of a warme stuff of divers colours , which they call tartane ” ( quoted in Skene ’ s Highlanders of Scotland , 2nd ed . , 148 ) .

86 . deich slatan singillte :
the amount of cloth required for the belted plaid . See BGh . , l . 1835 n .

109 . Breacan air am féile :
part of the tartan was pleated to make the kilt every time the belted plaid was put on . In an old song , Gillean an Fhéilidh ,
occur the lines —

Tha mo cheist - sa air gallain
Nan cuilbheirean glasa :
Guma slàn thig iad dachaidh
Fo ’ m breacan an éileadh .

112 . Nach éisd iad sradag :
they do not listen to a spark , i . e . they do not misfire .

119 . Còta geàrr :
Lesly , writing in 1578 of the dress worn by Highlanders , has the following — “ Reliqua vero vestimenta erant

brevis ex lana tunicella manicis inferius apertis … ” ( The rest of their garments consisted of a short woollen jacket with the sleeves open below … ) ( quoted in Skene ’ s Highlanders of Scotland , 2nd ed . , 144 ) .

120 . sléisdean nochdte :
in 1512 John Major remarks of the Highlanders , “ A medio crure ad pedem caligas non habent … frequenter nudis tibiis sub cruribus … ” ( From the middle of the thigh to the foot they have no covering for the leg … their legs are frequently naked under the thigh … ) ( quoted in Skene ’ s Highlanders of Scotland , 2nd ed . , 145 ) . Sacheveril , writing in 1688 , mentions the same feature , saying that “ Their thighs are bear , with brawny muscles ” ( quoted ibid . , 144 ) .

131 . lannan Spàinneach :
frequently mentioned by bards of the clan period . See BGh . , l . 1858 n . Swords were also made in the Highlands . The MacDonalds of Sleat had as smiths and armourers a family of MacRurys whose office was hereditary , and who had the smiths ’ pennylands of Baile Mhic Gille - riabhaich in Trotternish in return for their services . A branch of the family officiated in the same capacity in North Uist . One of them , who learnt the art of working in iron and of farriery from his father as it has been handed down by the family tradition , is smith in the township of Malacleit at the present time .

159 . Deòrsa :
King George II already mentioned .

162 . am prionnsa òg :
Frederick Louis , Prince of Wales , born 6th January 1707 . Flora MacDonald is said to have been set at liberty through his intercession . Died 20th March 1751 as the result of an accident while playing tennis ( Dict . Nat . Biog . , vii , 675 ff . ) . A Latin poem on his death was sent by Donald Roy MacDonald of Baleshare to Bishop Forbes ( Lyon in Mourning , iii , 89 ) .

163 . Teàrlach :
Prince Charles Edward . The bard forgot , or ignored , the fact that his father , whom Jacobites regarded as King James III , was still alive ( he died in 1766 ) , and would become king in the event of his prophecy being fulfilled .

170 . Cóig ceud mìle Frangach :
the Jacobite policy was to overthrow the House of Hanover with the help of the French , who in the eighteenth century were the rivals of Britain on the continent of Europe and more particularly beyond the seas , where a race for colonial power was in progress . It seems probable that it was the absence of French help that chiefly prevented the

176 . A luaidheas an clò Catach :
a pun , which also appears in a song of earlier date by Alexander MacDonald ; see BGh . , l . 1880 n . Sutherland tweed is specially singled out because the northern clans were Whigs .

177 . a ’ mhuc :
members of the Hanoverian dynasty were often compared to German swine . Julia MacDonald of Keppoch says in one of her songs —
ORAN NA H - AOISE

Oran air sean aois ,
AMD . ; Diomoladh na sean Aois le Iain mac Codrum , am Bard Uisteach ,
S .

Alexander MacDonald published this song along with his own in 1751 , thus giving the impression , whether intentionally or not , that he was the author . Alexander Stewart attributes it to MacCodrum . He was in a position to know , for he was for a number of years parish schoolmaster at Tigharry in North Uist , and though he may not have known the bard personally , they must have had many mutual acquaintances . Present tradition on the point is quite clear . The bard , it is said , was one day employed roofing a house in the village of Hosta , when he observed a very old man , staff in hand , walking towards him . It was a stormy day , and MacCodrum noticed what difficulty he had in making headway against the wind , and how , when he reached a small burn in the vicinity called Abhainn nan Riaghan ,
he took some time walking up and down before he found a place where he could cross . He thereupon began the song while at work , standing on the wall
( tobhta )
of the house . There seems to be no reason to doubt this account . A false tradition would probably take the form of assuming , as has been done ( UB . , xlii ) , that the theme was

suggested by the bard ’ s personal experience of old age , which is disproved by the fact that the song was published twenty - eight years before his death . Oran na h - Aoise also appears in the third edition of MacDonald ’ s songs ( 1802 ) , but in the next edition ( 1834 ) it was omitted . The omission is remarked upon in the preface : “ Two poems which commonly appeared in the old editions , the one on Old Age , and the other on the merits and demerits of Whisky , are ascribed to John MacCodrum , a contemporary bard , whose works deserve to be collected and published by themselves . These two have great merit but they have been omitted here . They are to be found in the old collections published by Ronald Macdonald , and Alex . & Donald Stewart ” ( quoted from the reprint of 1839 ) .

185 . Cf . the proverb , Mar chloich a ’ ruith le gleann feasgar fann fogharaidh . Am Bard Mucanach ,
in his song on the massacre of Glen Coe , says ,

Och ! ’ s ann thàinig a ’ chreach oirnn
Mar gun teàrnadh a ’ chlach leis a ’ ghleann .

Shaoileadh gach neach a ’ dol seachad
Gum bu chlach le gleann e .
( GB . , ii , 20 . )

270 . a ’ chùirt :
perhaps the court at which the chief or his baron - baillie administered justice in virtue of his hereditary jurisdiction .
ORAN NA H - OIGE

and more of oral transmission , to judge from certain repetitions of phrase ( ll . 305 , 313 ; ll . 323 , 329 ) , and from instances of construction so loose as not to convey the author ’ s trend of thought with sufficient clarity ( particularly the seventh and tenth verses ) . At present the song is a good deal confused in traditional renderings with MacDonald ’ s Oran a ’ Gheamhraidh because of identity of metre and air . MacCodrum ’ s song contains two lines ( ll . 311 - 312 ) which also appear in Oran a ’ Gheamhraidh . This may be due to borrowing on the part of one or other of the bards ( it cannot be said which song was composed first ) or to a lapse of memory on the part of Donald Laing or some earlier traditional singer . It should be observed , however , that current tradition as known to the writer also gives the two lines in question .
It is impossible to assign even an approximate date to this song . It would appear to be a counterpart to Oran na h - Aoise and may , like it , belong to the period before 1751 .

325 . Mìos grianach :
i . e . April , the fourth month ; in Gaelic , An Giblein .

333 . Bailc - Bhealltainn :
in a note in UB . the phrase is explained as giving “ the idea of the soft , dewy weather so desirable in May , and so productive of the fertility depicted ” in the song . Rain is not infrequent at this time of the year , but it is generally light and not unpleasant . In the Instructions of King Cormac the best seasons are defined as follows —

Gem caín cuisnech ,
errach tirim gáethach ,
sam tur frossach ,
fogmar tromdrúchtach torthech .

379 . Solamh ’ s aig Iòb :
cf . 1 Kings iii , 13 ; Job i , 3 .
CARAID AGUS NÀMHAID AN UISGE - BHEATHA

Comh - radh , mar go b ’ ann eider caraid agus namhaid an Uisgebheatha ,
AMD . , E .
394 . Cf . the proverb , Chan fhiach cuirm gun a comhradh .

O hó Rati ,
O hì Rati ,
O hó Rati
Nan clòithean ;
Bu luath Rati
Le chuag chasan
Ri cruaidh shneachda
Gun bhrògan .

585 ff . Acquaintance is here shown with the process of distilling , whether from experience or observation . A diagram of a still , with the names of the parts , appears in Dwelly ’ s Dictionary s . v . poit - dhubh .
SMEÒRACH CHLANN DOMHNAILL

Le Eoin MacCodrum o Uist a Chinn a Tuath , alias ( no written above ) Eoin mac Fhearchair mhic Iomhair , An Smeorach ,
M . Smeorich Clann ( Chlann in Index ) Doibhnil , le Iain M ‘ Codrum o Uist , chinn a Tuath , alias , Iain M ‘ Fhearchair mhic Iobhair ,
E .

Thig an samhradh s thig an samh
Thig a Ghrian Ghobhlanach Gheal
Thig a mbradan as a bhruaich
Ach as a Nuaidh cho dtig mo mhac .
( Rel . Celt . , ii , 333 . )

Thig a ’ chuthag , thig an t - snag ,
Thig a h - uile h - ian g ’ a nead ,
Thig a ’ gheàrr as a ’ chuan ,
Ach cha tig — mo nuar ! — mo bhean .
( Carmina Gadelica , ii , 284 . )

633 . nach caol ri cois na mara :
an expressive phrase which probably refers to the wide belt of machair and arable land on the north and west of North Uist .

639 . ghèadhach :
wild geese are very numerous in Uist . The bards often speak of Uibhist nan cràdhgheadh ( Uist of the sheldrakes ) .

641 . chròiceach :
correctly glossed in M . as referring to kelp , which is made by the incineration of sea - ware . The proprietors of North Uist made huge sums from the kelp industry in the eighteenth century . Lord MacDonald alluded to the island on one occasion as his “ little Peru . ” The removal of the embargo upon Spanish barilla put an end to the boom , and since then the industry has been carried on only on a small scale . An old Uist song mentions the kind of wife the bard is looking for as follows :

Ged bha mi gòrach
’ S ann bha mi ’ n tòir
Air té bhuaileadh cròcan
’ S a ’ chròic gu teann .

eòrnach :
Uist is also often termed Uibhist an eòrna .
In a

Shiubhlainn leat a dh ’ Uibhist
Far am buidhicheadh an t - eòrna .

Ma théid thu dh ’ Uibhist an eòrna
Thoir bean bhòidheach dhachaidh leat .

652 . òr air chlachan :
another reference to the lucrative kelp industry . See l . 641 n .

653 ff . In describing his birthplace the bard proceeds from the particular to the general , i . e . he was born and brought up at Cladh Chomhghain in Aird an Runnair ,
which is a peninsula on the west of North Uist beyond the village of Hougharry , from which it is separated by a beautiful tidal bay called Tràigh nam Fadhailean .
On the western side of this bay is a rock known as Sgeir na Circe ,
wrongly identified by Beveridge ( North Uist , 266 ) with a huge boulder which stands about the middle of the peninsula , the name of which is Clach Mhór nam Peighinnean .
At the coast - line about one hundred yards north of Sgeir na Circe is the end of a green ridge of turf called Gàradh na h - Airde ,
which is the remains of a dyke built after the peninsula was taken away from the township of Houghharry ( c . 1828 ? ) when Captain Allan Cameron was factor for North Uist . Immediately to the south of this end of Gàradh na h - Airde are the turf - covered remains of MacCodrum ’ s birthplace , barely visible after the lapse of more than two hundred winters . The house probably faced the south ( the doorway cannot be traced ) and measured about thirty feet long by fifteen feet broad . It no doubt consisted of the usual butt and ben of the period . Near the north - east corner of the house there appears to have been another structure measuring approximately twenty feet from north to south and twelve feet from east to west . This was probably the barn in which he is said to have rehearsed his first song . It may appear strange that a house should have been situated in a cemetery , but Cladh Chomhghain had been disused for centuries before MacCodrum ’ s time , and the house is described as having stood on the edge of the former burial - ground
( an imeall a ’ chlaidh ) .
A slight mound several yards to the south of the house may be the sight of the small chapel which was situated in the middle of the cemetery . The dedication was to St Comgan . There are two saints of this

In the vicinity of Aird an Runnair there are many names of ecclesiastical origin — Cille Mhoire , Peighinn Moire , Eilean Drostain , Cille Chalmain , Cille Pheadair .
In the peninsula itself there do not seem to be any ancient remains other than Cladh Chomhghain ,
except perhaps one prominent mound on the high ground to the north which bears the curious name of Tobhta na Sgàrlaid .
If the place was ever densely populated there is no evidence of that now , for there are no other noticeable sites . The tacksmen to whom it belonged after Captain Allan Cameron ’ s time may , however , have destroyed such traces of occupation . In order to improve the pasture they removed as many stones from the land as they could . The numerous small cairns which dot the peninsula bear witness to those operations — such , at any rate , is the local belief .

Am fear nach dùraig a h - òl
Gun tuit an t - sùil air a ’ bhòrd as .
( E . , 197 . )
AN AGHAIDH FÀILTE NA MÓRTHIR

This is ascribed in North Uist to MacCodrum . The third verse is the best known ; it appears in UB . ( p . xxxiv ) and is there attributed to him . The third , fourth , and sixth verses were known to Maclean Sinclair , who published them in the Maclean Bards ( i , 251 ) , but he attributes them to An t - Aireach Muileach . It would be quite in keeping with what is known of the latter that he should compose a song contradicting Alexander MacDonald : MacDonald did the like to his condemnation of An Caimbeulach Dubh .
But the first two verses can hardly be

More verses of the song given here may still come to light . It may be that the extra verse introduced into Fàilte na Mórthir in the 1923 edition of MacDonald ’ s songs may properly belong to the description of Uist of which the first two verses are part :

Tìr ’ m bi pailteas
Coirc ’ is eòrna ,
Beoir fo shop is dram innt ’ .
The mention of barley suggests Uist rather than the Mórthir ( cf . l . 641 n . ) .

A ’ choill gu h - uilidh
Fo làn duillich ,
’ S i ’ n a culaidh bhainnse .

695 . A ’ Mhórthir :
in Uist and the Small Isles this was used in the particular sense of the mainland territory of Clan Ranald , i . e . Knoydart , Morar , Arisaig , and Moidart . It can be distinguished in Gaelic from Morar ( apart from spelling ) by the fact that the latter does not take the article .

696 . calltuinn :
hazel was regarded of old in the Highlands as unlucky and as a useless timber .

Na minn bheaga
Dol ’ s na creagan ,
’ S iad ri ceigeis ghreannmhoir .

Mnathan aoibhinn
Mòdhar coibhneil ,
Làn de loinn ’ s de bhaindeachd .

Fir làn sonais ,
Saor bho dhonas ,
Gun dad conais - dranndain .
AOIR DHOMHNAILL FRISEIL

715 . Céile mhic Shir Seumas :
it has been suggested ( UB . , xxi , 62 ) that this was the widow of Ranald , natural son of Sir James MacDonald , second baronet of Sleat , who was known as Raghnall mac Shir Seumas ,
and from whom were descended the MacDonalds of Baleshare . She was Marion , daughter of Donald MacDonald , thirteenth of Clan Ranald , and relict of Allan

716 . éighreachd Chloinn Mhic Cuinn :
the island of Oransay and adjoining lands on the mainland of North Uist were occupied by a family of MacQueens from an early period . The original tack is said to have been a verbal one ; it was to endure —

Fhad ’ s a bhios bainne aig boin duibh
No Cnògaire Mhic Cuinn ’ n a bhun .

( The Cnògaire is a hill on their former territories on the mainland of North Uist . ) Early in the seventeenth century they received a more modern guarantee of their tenure . Kenneth MacQueen appears under North Uist in the Valuation Roll of Inverness - shire in 1691 , when his estate was worth £160 ( Fraser - Mackintosh , Antiquarian Notes , 1st Series , 56 ) . In 1718 Oransay was held by Kenneth MacQueen for 240 merks Scots and rent in kind to the extent of 8 bolls victuals and 24 st . butter ( Clan Donald , iii , 110 , 660 ) .

757 . am Bàideanach :
so called , according to one authority ( UB . , xxi ) , because he was a native of Badenoch . There are , however , reasons for thinking that the Bàideanach ,
despite his name , was a Uistman . It is to be observed that , in this and the following song , he seems to be introduced , not because he was specially disliked , but because he was unfortunate enough to be a near neighbour of the notorious Fraser and so came into conflict with him oftener than others , especially if , as seems likely , he had a fiery temper . His sobriquet was that of others in Uist as well , and was applied to descendants of Domhnall Bàideanach ( fl . c . 1510 ) , a son of Domhnall Hearach ,
the progenitor of the MacDonalds of Griminish and Balranald , and a woman from Badenoch ( Clan Donald , iii , 482 ) .

758 . Lì :
this is the name of two hills ( Lì bho Thuath and Lì bho Dheas ) on the east side of North Uist between Loch Maddy and Loch Eford . Cf . l . 2546 n .

765 - 766 . The way in which the price of the heifer is given ( partly in merks and partly in pounds Scots ) is peculiar , and if the reason is metrical , it argues considerable arithmetical ability in a bard who had no school education . The price in pounds Scots would be £11 , 13s . 4d . , i . e . 19s . 5d . sterling .
A ’ CHOIMHSTRITH

Air Connstrith Edir Diais ann Uibhist a Cheinne - tuath Leis an Ian Mac Codrum cheudna ,
M . , G . A Chomhstri eadar Domhnull Friseal agus Domhnull Bàideanach ,
UB .
The two principals in the quarrel were Donald Fraser , the subject of the foregoing song , and Am Bàideanach ( ? Donald MacDonald ) , mentioned in the same song . The date of the piece is c . 1758 .

778 . Leòdach :
MacLeod was perhaps the man mentioned in the seventh verse who brought the news that the old enemies had made peace .

797 . an Diùc :
the Duke of Cumberland .

798 . rìgh Phruisia :
Frederick II , king of Prussia , better known as Frederick the Great . Frederick had just distinguished himself by gaining the brilliant victories of Rossbach and Leuthen ( 1757 ) . His defeat by the Russians at Kunersdorf ( 1759 ) had probably not taken place when the song was composed .

814 . Pabaidh :
a large island in the Sound of Harris which supported a considerable population in the eighteenth century . It is now occupied by two shepherds .

844 . North Uist — though there are indications that at one time it was well wooded — has been dependent in historic times on outside sources for its supply of timber . Frequent voyages were made to the opposite mainland coasts of Inverness - shire and Argyll and to Mull for cargoes of wood . This was called dol dh ’ an Choille .
It is possible that this source of supply was temporarily closed when the song was composed .

848 . Mac Fhionnlaigh :
he is said to have been a Morrison from Clachan Sand , belonging to a family which originated in the Isle of Pabbay , several of the members of which were smiths , including the religious bard of Harris , John Morrison . His family is still represented in North Uist . His part in the story is difficult to understand , unless it was to supply the combatants with weapons .
849 . Tha an dà iarann deug ’ s an teallach aige is a saying used to describe a very busy person .

864 . an Dotair :
Niel Beaton , the last of a branch of the famous MacBeth family of physicians to hold hereditary office from the house of Sleat in North Uist . He died in 1763 ( Clan Donald , iii , 128 ) . His great - grandson , John Beaton
( Iain mac Fhearchair mhic Iain mhic Nèill Dhotair ) ,
a shepherd at Corodale in South Uist , died in 1881 at the age of ninety - two . He had no school education , but had a wonderful knowledge of herbs . He had a son named Farquhar ( Carmina Gadelica , ii , 80 ) .

868 . Uisdean :
Hugh MacDonald of Baleshare , for whom see notes on Marbhrann do Uisdean a ’ Bhaile Shear .

869 . Dh ’ Fhear Bhàlaidh :
Ewen MacDonald of Vallay , third son of William , Tutor of MacDonald , and grandson of Sir Donald MacDonald , third baronet of Sleat . He came to Vallay in 1727 , and from 1733 to 1740 acted as MacDonald ’ s factor for North Uist . He was known in Uist as Eóghan mac an Taoiteir ,
and

is said to have been a true Highland gentleman
( fìor dhuine uasal còir ) .
He married Mary , daughter of Rev . Lauchlan Maclean , minister of Coll . She is not favourably spoken of by tradition . Ewen was an excellent piper , and was also a composer of pipe music . When Sir James MacDonald was accidentally shot in the foot while on a visit to North Uist and taken to Vallay , the Goodman of Vallay composed a pibroch known as Cumha na Coise ,
with which are associated the following words :

Mo ghaol , mo ghaol
Do chas threubhach
Dh ’ an tig an t - osan
’ S am féileadh ;
Bu leat toiseach
Nan ceudan
’ N am féidh
Bhith ’ g an ruith .
( Clan Donald , iii , 542 - 543 . )

870 . D ’ an Bhàillidh :
Alexander MacDonald of Hougharry , for whom see notes on Marbhrann do Alasdair mac Dhomhnaill .

877 . MacCruimein :
Pàdruig Mór MacCrimmon . See l . 890 ff . n .

878 . Con - duiligh :
he was perhaps the best known of the Rankins , who acted as hereditary pipers to the Macleans of Duart . He flourished in the first part of the eighteenth century , and was present with his chief , Sir John Maclean , at the Battle of Sheriffmuir . It is said that when the battle started he gave his pipes to a servant lad to guard and rushed into the thick of the fray . When the right of Mar ’ s army , in which he was fighting , routed their opponents , he returned to retrieve the pipes , but they were not to be found ; the boy had taken fright and run away . A Coll bard , Lachlan Maclean
( Lachlann mac mhic Iain ) ,
composed a song against the pipes in which he makes satirical use of the incident :

Tha ’ m dhìth , tha ’ m dhìth ,
Tha ’ m dhìth gu buileach ,
Clann Duiligh ’ s a ’ phìob
Tha ’ m dhìth gu buileach .
’ N am gleusadh nam pìob
Bu bhinn an luinneag ;
’ S iad thogadh am fonn
Neo - throm ’ s a ’ chuideachd .
This Hector had a son called Neil who was piper to Maclean of Coll and accompanied Alasdair Ruadh in the Earl of Breadalbane ’ s

The family claimed descent from Cù - duiligh mac Raing , who was the great - great - grandfather of Gill - Eathain na Tuaighe , from whom are descended the Clan Maclean . He was the first of the ancestors of the Macleans who lived in Argyll . After him the Rankins were of old called Clann Chon - duiligh and later Clann Duiligh .
Later still they began to call themselves Clann Mhic Raing ( Rankin ) , bringing in the earlier name in the genealogy .

When they became pipers to the Macleans is not known , but there is no doubt that by the eighteenth century they had for long possessed a great reputation . Their school of piping at Kilbrennan in Torloisk was attended by young men from all over the Highlands . With the decline of the fortunes of the Macleans of Duart it gradually lost its former glory . In 1760 , the year in which it ceased to function , the pupils of Eóghan mac Eachainn mhic Chon - duiligh numbered only seventeen .

Càit ’ a bheil anns a ’ chruitheachd
Aon mhic mnà thug ort urram
Ann an uaislead ’ s an grinnead ,
Ann an deirgead ’ s an gilead ,
Mach bho phearsa Chloinn Duiligh ,
Is bho Phàdruig MacCruimein ?
( MT . , xii , No . 2 . )

Teàrlach :
Charles MacArthur , the most celebrated of the hereditary pipers of the Sleat family , who was a contemporary of MacCodrum . The MacArthurs occupied the lands of Hunglater in Trotternish in virtue of their office . They were supposed to be a branch of the MacArthurs of Proaig in Islay , who acted as pipers and armourers to the MacDonalds of the Isles . Charles had the advantage of being under the tuition of Pàdruig Og MacCrimmon for eleven years . When Sir Alexander

MacDonald was a student in St Andrews ( 1726 - 1729 ) Charles MacArthur was in attendance as his piper . He was also piper to the next two chiefs . His salary in 1749 was £66 , 13s . 4d . Scots . Among his compositions is a lament for Sir James MacDonald published in General Thomason ’ s Ceòl Mór . The date of his death is not recorded ; he was living in 1774 , in which year Pennant visited him . At that time he must have been an old man , and he probably did not survive that decade . Over his grave in Kilmuir , Skye , is a recumbent stone with the following inscription :

HERE LY
THE REMAINS OF
CHARLES MAC
KARTER WHOSE
FAME AS AN HON
EST MAN AND
REMARKABLE PIP
ER WILL SURVIVE
THIS GENERATION
FOR HIS MANNERS
WERE EASY & REG
ULAR AS HIS
MUSIC & THE
THE MELODY OF
HIS FINGERS
WILL

The unfinished state of the inscription is due to the fact that the local mason who executed it was receiving , or was to receive , certain sums in commission from Charles ’ s son Donald while the work was still in progress . This arrangement fell through when Donald met his death suddenly by drowning while ferrying cattle from Uist to Skye . Charles MacArthur had another son named Alexander who is said to have emigrated to America . Shortly after 1800 , he petitioned Lord MacDonald to appoint him his piper , describing himself as the only male representative of the family then living . Better known in North Uist than Charles MacArthur was his brother John ( Iain Bàn ) , who was official piper to Sir Alexander MacDonald there in 1745 with a salary of £33 , 6s . 8d . His son Angus was piper to Lord MacDonald and died in London in 1800 , the last holder of the office . A second brother , Neil , had a son John , who was instructed in the art of piping by his celebrated uncle . John took up residence in

891 . B ’ e MacCruimein an rìgh :
it is almost certain that the piper MacCodrum had in mind was Pàdruig Mór MacCrimmon , the most renowned of his line . With the statement that he was king of pipers compare the following from the Wardlaw MS . ( pp . 379 - 380 ) : “ All the pipers in the army gave John Macgurmen [MacCrimmon] the van , and acknowledged him for their patron in chiefe . It was pretty in a morning ( the King ) in parad viewing the regiments and bragads . He saw no less than 80 pipers in a crould bareheaded , and John M ’ gyurmen in the midle covered . He asked What society that was ? It was told his Majesty : Sir , yow are our King , and yonder old man in the midle is the Prince of Pipers . He cald him by name , and , comeing to the King , kneeling , his Majesty reacht him his hand to kiss ; and [ ? he] instantly played an extemporanian part [i . e . port] Fuoris Pooge i spoge i Rhī [Fuaras pòg a ( i . e . de ) spòg a ( n ) Rìgh] , I got a kiss of the Kings hand ; of which he and they all were vain . ” According to the author of the MS . the above incident occurred in May 1651 , a few weeks before the battle of Inverkeithing , when Charles II and the royalist forces were stationed at Stirling . The usual tradition , among pipers and in the Isles , has been that the author of the pibroch , Thug mi pòg do làimh an Rìgh ,
was Pàdruig Mór , and that he composed it when he kissed the hand of Charles II while on a visit to London with Roderick MacLeod of Talisker after the Restoration ( cf . Mackenzie ’ s History of the MacLeods , 103 ) . The Wardlaw MS . , written by a contemporary , is probably right as regards the occasion and date of the composition ; as regards the piper ’ s first name even a contemporary might err . That there is an error is suggested by the fact that there does not seem to be any further trace of a John MacCrimmon in the family during the seventeenth century . The supremacy of the MacCrimmons among pipers was apparently acknowledged long before 1651 , but as MacCodrum seems to be referring to one particular member of the family , his words may possibly refer almost directly to the Stirling incident — one among many instances of his knowledge of Highland history . That it was Pàdruig Mór he had in mind is confirmed by his reference to the Oinseach ( l . 900 ) , a set of pipes usually associated with Pàdruig . It is true that Alexander MacDonald has a song in praise of “ MacCrimmon ’ s Pipes , called the Idiot , ” which would appear

to indicate that the owner was his contemporary , Domhnall Bàn .
It is very likely , however , that the same instrument might be used by several generations of pipers .

903 . A ’ bhàirisgeach :
it may be that a proper name is intended here — A ’ Bhàirisgeach — by which Charles MacArthur ’ s pipes may have been known , just as MacCrimmon ’ s pipes were designated An Oinseach .

929 . luchd nam beul fiara :
the Campbells . Gaelic Caimbeul = cam + beul ( wry mouth ) .

946 . o - dròchain :
MacCodrum was probably well versed in pipe music , as a listener if not as a player , and , like many others at that time , had some knowledge of canntaireachd ,
the vocal method of rendering pipe tunes . The MacCrimmons and the MacArthurs each had a system of canntaireachd , and there were several other systems . Further examples of MacCodrum ’ s knowledge of canntaireachd will be seen in ll . 967 , 968 , 969 , 970 , 977 , 992 , 1071 .

994 . Maol - Ruanaidh O Dòrnan :
“ A wandering Irish piper , whose music the Highlanders could not appreciate ” ( SO . , 149 ) . “ A wandering Irish harper whose piping was unacceptable to the Highlanders ” ( UB . , 53 ) . Even as late as the eighteenth

997 . MacBheatrais :
several of this name are mentioned in the records of the Privy Council and elsewhere as fighting men in the following of the MacDonalds of Sleat . In the Lord High Treasurer ’ s Accounts for the year 1503 there is recorded — “ Item to Makberty , the clarisha to pass to the Isles , iijb . xs . ” Other individuals of this name appear as harpers in Galloway . It may be another form of the one used by MacCodrum . Still another form may be MacBeathaig , which was the name of the Sleat bard , Uilleam MacBeathaig . It is possible that the reference is to him . As a predecessor of MacCodrum , it may be of interest to give what little is known of him and his verse here .

Chan fheudar beanailt ri luchd na comhladh
’ S ann de m ’ iongnadh ;
Fhuair sibh tigh agus leth Alba
Le neart bhur daoine ;
Mac Fhionghuin , Mac Gill - Eathain ,
Mac Leoid Leódhuis —
Triuir bha feitheamh dreuchd
An teach Mhic Dhomhnaill ;
Fear - ionaid Mhic Leoid a Dùn Bheagain
Dorsair seòmair ,
Is bu mhath an inbhe dha
Bhith feitheamh comhlaidh ;
Morair Hunndaidh nan each seanga
Dh ’ am biodh mórshluagh —
Bhiodh esan am freasdail stioraip
An am teàrnaidh ;
Fhuair iad duais mhath a cheann sin —
Bàideanach o cheann gu ceann dith
Aca tha i ,
Aca tha i .
MacLeod ’ s lady was delighted , and gave the bard a suit of the clò breac sgàrlaid .

The MacBheatrais alias may perhaps be conceded to MacBeathaig . Beathag ,
usually translated Sophia , is rendered Beatrice by a Uistman , Rev . James MacDonald , in his General View of Agriculture in the Hebrides ( p . 705 ) , published in 1811 . This may indicate some traditional connexion . The MacArthur alias sounds less probable , but MacBeathaig no doubt played the pipes where his predecessors had played the harp , which had lost its popularity . His skill was not great , to judge from MacCodrum ’ s allusion . Perhaps the office of piper had not yet become a distinct one in the MacDonald retinue . MacBeathaig ’ s floruit may perhaps be placed in the beginning of the seventeenth century . The Domhnall Gorm he mentions is evidently the second chief of that name , known as Domhnall Gorm Mór ,
who died without issue in 1617 . Tradition has evidently confused the relationship with MacLeod , for it was the reverse of that stated in the story — MacDonald married as his first wife Mary , daughter of Norman MacLeod of Dunvegan , and subsequently repudiated her , in circumstances well known to Island tradition ( Celtic Magazine , vii , 21 - 23 ; UB . , 53 ; Clan Donald , iii , 124 , 470 ) .

1005 . Seachd cathan nam Fiantaidh :
the Fian consisted of seven battalions in time of war and three in time of peace . Each battalion numbered three thousand men , as the gloss in M . correctly states . Keating ’ s account , which is the authority for the above , is as follows : “ Is é gnáthshluagh do bhíodh ar buannacht fá Fhionn trí catha na Gnáithfhéine , agus trí mhíle san chath , an tan fá síodhach fir Eireann ré chéile . Gidheadh an tan do fhásadh easaonta idir aonlucht d ’ uaislibh Eireann agus an t - airdrígh , no an tan fá héigean sluagh do chur i nAlbain do neartughadh Dál Riada i n - aghaidh allmhurrach , do bhíodh seacht gcatha ag Fionn , ionnus go mbíodh furthainn sluagh aige ré dul d ’ fhurtacht Dál Riada i nAlbain agus ré hEirinn do

1007 . Dhiarmaid is Ghuill :
Diarmaid O Duibhne , one of the most renowned of the Fian , and Goll mac Mòrna , head of the Clann Mòrna , who was associated with them . For Island tradition regarding them see Gregorson Campbell , The Fians , 49 - 63 .

1009 . Iain Og :
not identified .

1014 . mac Eachainn :
also unidentified ; unless it is he who is referred to in the following port - a - beul —

Cas Odhar was a nickname acquired by the piper as a little boy because when practising on the chanter and keeping time with his foot , his mother used to say , “ Nach seall sibh air a ’ chas odhar . ” Nighean Eóghain was a poor woman
( cailleach a bhiodh a ’ faoigh )
from the Paible district .

1015 . sliabh Chnoc - an - Lìn :
a village in Paible on the rising ground south of Bayhead . It got its name at a time when flax was grown in the island .

1025 . inneadh air aodach : inneadh is a lack of thread when there is a web in the loom , and the amount required to make good the deficiency . It is considered unlucky to refuse a request for thread to complete a web . An Island legend tells how the Virgin Mary gave to a poor woman who asked her for inneadh a lock of her hair , which miraculously completed the web .

tuar tuirse tafann a lámh ,
blas na gcrann gafann ’ na ngeóin .
( Measgra Dánta , i , 7 . )

1053 . Còrr was apparently used as a term of contempt , either by itself or prefixed to another word . Cf . Keating , speaking of Colum Cille ’ s arrival at the Convention of Druim Ceat , “ adubhairt an ríoghan … gan cádhas do thabhairt don choirr - chléireach ná dhá bhuidhin ”
which is explained in O ’ Donnell ’ s Betha Coluimb Chille as samhlughadh re cuirr ,
“ likening him to a heron . ” The “ lewd fellows of the baser sort ” mentioned in the Acts of the Apostles ( xvii , 5 ) appear in Gaelic as
“ droch dhaoine àraidh de na corraibh - margaidh . ”
The word also occurs in the Gaelic saying , Aithris an darna curra air a ’ churra eile ( One worthless woman ’ s reproach of another ) . The use of the word in such contexts perhaps originated in the fact that the heron was regarded as an ungainly bird ( Bergin , Stories from Keating ’ s History of Ireland , 39 , 94 ; Gregorson Campbell , The Fians , 47 ) . The figures seen by gazing steadily into the fire , of old regarded as spirits , are called corracha cagailt .
Cf . Neil MacVurich in Seanchas na Pìoba bho Thùs :

Pìob sgreadain Iain MhicArtuir
Mar eun curra air dol air n - ais

Seinnidh corra - ghlùineach a ghafainn
Fuaim trùilich an tafainn sheirbh .
( G . , 292 . )

1073 . ochdnar :
the eight fingers used to play the bagpipes .
1076 - 1077 . Cf . Lachlan Maclean in Diomoladh na Pìoba already mentioned :

Gum b ’ fheàrr i mar chlachbhalg
Chur nan each bhàrr an fheoir
Na bhrosnachadh sluaigh .
( Rel . Celt . , ii , 340 ; GB . , i , 127 . )

1078 . Duan chur as frìthe :
the meaning seems uncertain . Perhaps “ a rime ( incantation ? ) for putting out a heath fire , ”

1082 . MacPhàil :
John MacPhail , the author of the panegyric on Domhnall Bàn , as already mentioned . Two persons of this name appear in the Rent Roll of I718 , one in Baile Mhic Conain and one in Clachan Sand ( Clan Donald , iii , 659 ) . The MacPhails seem to have been a clan of old standing in North Uist , and were at one time numerous in the Sand district . Their ancestor was probably he who gave his name to Baile Mhic Phàil and Loch Mhic Phàil ,
both of which are in that district . A Norse chief , Paul Balkeson , still remembered in the tradition of MacCodrum ’ s time as Pàl Bacach ,
was powerful in this region at the end of the twelfth and the beginning of the thirteenth century , and it is probable that the Uist MacPhails are descended from him . They are said to have been an influential tribe in the island at one time . Neil MacVicar
( Niall Ruadh Mór ) ,
a Uist bard who flourished upwards of a century ago , composed a song in which he made two Uistmen of the time , Roderick MacDonald and Archibald MacPhail , indulge in wordy warfare . Their ancestors are discussed at some length . MacPhail thus refers to his :

A Ruairidh spàgaich mhic Ailein
Chaill thu thairis do nàire
’ N uair a theann thu ri m ’ aoireadh
’ S mi shliochd - dhaoine ro làidir ;
Bha mi uair ann an Sannda
Bhiodh do cheann - s ’ air dhroch càradh
Air son do chantanais dhomhsa :
Gu robh gu leòr Chlann Mhic Phàil ann
De ghillean smart .
ORAN NAM BANTRAICHEAN

not mentioned by name . One was a MacCuish from Cladach Baleshare , one was a Ferguson from Sand , and the third was from Sollas , but enquiries as to her name have so far been unsuccessful . The first - mentioned was , according to tradition , a near neighbour of the then youthful Gille na Ciotaig .
John , notwithstanding their determined efforts , did not marry any of them or of the other widows of the island when he took a third wife .

1091 . Shannda :
Sannda is a general name for the district in North Uist to the south of the Sound of Bernera . Before the era of evictions and emigration it supported a large population . In 1718 its five villages
( Baile Mhic Phàil , Baile Mhic Conain , Clachan , Rùmaisgearraidh ,
and Bhàlacuidh )
were divided between thirty - seven tenants ( Clan Donald , iii , 659 ) . In 1794 the population was 800 ( Old Stat . Acc . , xiii , 316 ) . The people were removed when Captain Allan Cameron was factor .

Sholas : Solas is a general name for the district on the north side of North Uist between Ceann Tràigh Bhàlaidh on the west and Cnoc Mhic Eóghain on the east . It is at present divided into four townships the names of which are in Gaelic ( proceeding from west to east ) , Malacleit , Ceathramh Meadhonach , Solas ,
and Greunatobht .
In 1718 only the first two of these were occupied by small tenants holding directly from the proprietor . The name Solas was originally applied to an old holding occupying the high ground between the present townships of Sollas and Grenetote south of the main road , and may still be heard applied to that spot . The present township of Sollas , set up by the Congested Districts Board about 1900 , and occupying the land between Grenetote and Middlequarter
( Ceathramh Meadhonach ) ,
includes the ancient holdings of Sollas
( Solas ) ,
Havisgarry
( Hàbhaisgearraidh ) ,
Misigarry
( Misegearraidh ) , ( ? ) Gerrina - curran
( Gearraidh - nan - curran ) ,
and Doun
( An Dùn )
( see Beveridge ’ s North Uist , 93 - 94 ) .

1103 . bàillidh an tighearn :
Alexander MacDonald , for whom see notes on Marbhrann do Alasdair mac Dhomhnaill .

1107 . Fear Ghrìminis :
John MacDonald of Griminish . During his father ’ s lifetime he occupied Scolpig . He died in 1765 ( Clan Donald , iii , 485 ) . The MacDonalds of Griminish were descended from Domhnall Hearach ,
a younger son of Hugh MacDonald of Sleat and a daughter of MacLeod of Harris . He and his descendants occupied Griminish and Scolpig for nearly three hundred years ( c . 1500 - c . 1790 ) . Towards the end of

the eighteenth century the main line became extinct and the representation of Clann Dhomhnaill Hearaich devolved upon the MacDonalds of Balranald . The most celebrated of the MacDonalds of Griminish in the traditions of North Uist is Iain mac Uisdein ,
fifth of the line , who died in his ninety - fourth year c . 1700 ( Martin ’ s Description , 1934 ed . , 146 ) .
RANN DO ’ N LÀIR
ORAN A ’ BHONN - A - SIA

1143 . tigh air an laimrig :
the present pier at Loch Eford is on the opposite shore of the loch from Langash , but which laimrig is meant here is uncertain . The bard was evidently not returning home that night . He and his seven companions ( l . 1203 ) were staying in the house near the landing - stage until morning .

1145 . Aonghus MacAmhlaidh :
Angus MacAulay was perhaps the owner of the house .

1156 . an clachan :
simply “ the hamlet , ” and probably not Clachan nan Cluip ,
a village nearly two miles due west from the head of Loch Eford .

1157 . rathad na Leacaich :
the only Leacach known to the writer is situated on the east side of Loch Obisary and is sometimes more fully referred to as Leacach Loch Obasairigh .
If this is the place intended in the text then it may be that the ferrying operations were carried out somewhere in the Eaval peninsula — where the old North Uist market stance was in those days — perhaps in the vicinity of Clachan Biùrabhal at the mouth of Loch Eford , but where the whisky was to be procured is hard to say . It was evidently not at the inn at Rudha Eubhadh .
To make the unfortunate Angus undertake the long journey to the inn at Carinish would undoubtedly enhance the effect of the dénouement for which the bard is preparing , and it may be , therefore , that the clachan mentioned in l . 1156 is Carinish . To go from Clachan Biùrabhal to Carinish there are two routes which may be taken on foot , the one by the east of Eaval and the other by the west . These routes are about equal in length , but the latter is the easier and is apparently the one recommended in the song .

1159 . Teàrlach :
the inn - keeper , who is not further identified .

1174 . dealbh na clàrsaich :
this is interesting as showing that the halfpenny was an Irish one — the harp appears only on Irish coins . No Irish money was struck during the reign of Queen Anne , and the inn - keeper ’ s reference to cùinneadh na ban - righ was therefore mistaken . An examination of the various halfpence in circulation after the Revolution leads to the conclusion that the honest Charles failed to recognise the laureated head of George II , which is not unlike that of Queen Anne . A large issue of Irish halfpence , amounting to fifty tons of copper , was made in George II ’ s reign at various dates between 1736 and 1755 . The obverse was inscribed Georgius Rex ( the omission of Dei Gratia gave rise to criticism ) ; the reverse , besides the crown and the harp , bore the one word Hibernia and the date . As the conversation between Charles and MacAulay is probably imaginary , the mistake is MacCodrum ’ s and bears out ( though it does not prove ) the tradition that he could not read . The tone of Charles ’ s remarks further indicates that Irish money was well known at the time . Even as late as the eighteenth century there was considerable intercourse with Ireland . Drovers , like Roderick MacLeod , frequently visited there . Murchadh Ruadh nam Bó ,
the author of the original Hó mo Mhàiri Laghach ,
is said to have heard his song sung in an inn in Ireland while there
on a droving expedition . The Gaelic for “ heads and tails ” in the Isles to this day is ceann is clàrsach .

1180 . Ruairidh an dròbhair :
Roderick MacLeod of Borline , as already mentioned . The MacLeods of Borline were descended from Norman , second son of Uilleam Cléireach ,
fifth Chief of Dunvegan , whose descendants were known as Clann Mhic ’ ic Uilleim .
They possessed Borline for a number of generations . There does not seem to be any genealogical information available regarding this branch of the MacLeods . William MacLeod of Borline , captain in the 73rd Regiment , was perhaps Roderick ’ s son . Roderick ’ s children were young when the song was composed c . 1760 ( l . 2954 ) . Mackenzie ( History of the MacLeods , 273 ) mentions another member of the “ ancient family of Borline , ” William Comperus MacLeod , who was born c . 1815 . Others of the family emigrated to North Carolina . Mary MacLeod , the poetess , was of the same stock , being descended from Alasdair Ruadh ( not to be confused with her father ) , second son of Norman mentioned above ( Bannatyne MS . , quoted in Canon R . C . MacLeod ’ s The MacLeods of Dunvegan , 58 ) .

1183 . Tormod a Uinis :
Norman MacLeod of Unish , eldest son of Donald MacLeod of Bernera . In 1739 he was deeply implicated in the kidnapping of numbers of Islanders for the purpose of transporting them to the American plantations . A ship ( known to posterity as Soitheach nan Daoine ) actually set sail but was wrecked on the coast of Ireland without loss of life . Only a few of its occupants , however , made their way back to the Isles . After this exploit Norman spent some time in hiding in Ireland . When the Rising of 1745 took place he left Ireland and joined the forces of the Government . On the death of his father in 1783 he became tacksman of Bernera , and in the following year succeeded Alexander MacLeod of Muiravonside as representative of the Bernera family ( Mackenzie ’ s History of the MacLeods , 255 ff . ) .

1184 . Uilleam a Os :
William MacLeod of Ose , who was married to Christian , eighth child of Donald MacLeod of Bernera , and sister of the Goodman of Unish ( Mackenzie ’ s History of the MacLeods , 252 ) . The MacLeods of Ose were descended from Alexander of Minginish , third son of Norman , eleventh Chief of Dunvegan ( Canon R . C . MacLeod ’ s The MacLeods of Dunvegan , 100 ) . Genealogical details do not appear to be extant .

1185 . Tormod eile :
in all probability MacCodrum means Norman MacLeod , fourth of Greshornish , who succeeded his father , Rev . Donald MacLeod , at one time parish minister of North Uist ( 1736 - 1754 ) , on the latter ’ s death , which took place probably towards the end of 1759 ( his death is noted in the Scots Magazine of 12th January 1760 ) . Norman was married to his cousin , Margaret , daughter of Alexander MacLeod of Ullinish
( an Siorram ) ,
whom MacCodrum mentions . Boswell met and admired her in her father ’ s house . Norman MacLeod of Greshornish was still living in 1798 ( Mackenzie ’ s History of the MacLeods , 268 - 269 ) .

an Siorram :
Alexander MacLeod , Sheriff - substitute of Skye , second son of Roderick MacLeod , first of Ullinish , and great - grandson of Sir Roderick Mór , thirteenth Chief of Dunvegan . He entertained Dr Johnson at Ullinish in 1773 . Boswell says , “ Mr MacLeod of Ulinish , the Sheriff - substitute of the island , was a plain honest gentleman , a good deal like an English justice of peace ; not much given to talk , but sufficiently sagacious and somewhat droll ” ( Mackenzie ’ s History of the MacLeods , 270 , 275 ff . ) .

1191 . Fear Fearann - an - Léigh :
probably Alexander MacLeod of Ferinlea , who is on record in 1746 ( More Culloden Papers , iv , 179 ) . Like MacLeod of Ose , he was married to one of Donald MacLeod of Bernera ’ s numerous progeny ( Mackenzie ’ s History of the MacLeods , 252 ) . The genealogy of this branch of the MacLeods has apparently still to be traced . Cf . Boswell ’ s Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides , 1936 ed . , 212 - 213 .
MARBHRANN DO ALASDAIR MAC DHOMHNAILL

1219 . Gill - easbuig :
it is impossible to be certain as to the identity of the persons mentioned in this line and the next . This is perhaps Archibald MacDonald of Griminish , sixth in descent from Domhnall Hearach , who died in 1740 ( Clan Donald , iii , 485 ) .

1220 . Eoin :
probably Captain John MacDonald of Kirkibost , fifth son of William , Tutor of MacDonald . In 1735 he had the tack of Kendrom in Trotternish , and acted as bailie for the barony . In 1740 he obtained from Sir Alexander MacDonald a tack of the lands of Kirkibost , Kyles , and Balranald in North Uist . About the same time he was appointed factor for the North Uist estate . He had command of one of the Independent Companies in 1745 , but he was no doubt at heart favourably disposed towards the Jacobites . When Ned Burke was in hiding in Eaval in the summer of 1746 , a near relative of his , Peter MacDonald , gave information against him to Captain MacDonald , who broke a staff over his head “ for telling lies ” ( Lyon in Mourning , i , 197 ) . Captain MacDonald died before 1750 ( Clan Donald , iii , 541 ) .

1263 . do chéile :
Catherine , daughter of Maclean of Boreray , as already mentioned . Commiseration for the widow was a regular feature of elegies by bards both trained and vernacular .

Fasan bu dual
Fantalach buan ,
Socrach ri tuaith ,
etc .
( J . Carmichael Watson ’ s Gaelic Songs of Mary MacLeod , 64 . )

Cha b ’ e ’ n cleachdadh bh ’ aig càch
So ghlac thu mar ghnàths
Bhith smachdail m ’ an mhàl air tuaith .
( E . , 102 . )

1288 . an Di - ciadaoin mu dheireadh de ’ n Mhàrt :
the day on which MacDonald was found drowned . Assuming that he died on the same day on which his body was found , the date of his death was thus 27th March 1760 .

1296 . Di - màirt :
evidently the day of the funeral — 2nd April 1760 .

1301 - 1302 . The idea evidently is that others would have wished that he should have died on the field of battle or at home
( bàs a ’ chinn - adhairt ) .
In the old tales these two kinds of death were contrasted , the one being sometimes spoken of as bás do rinn ( death from a spear - point ) and the other as éc fri adart and bás re hadart ( O ’ Keeffe , Buile Suibhne , Mediæval and Modern Irish Series , i , 3 , 85 ; Stokes and Windisch , Acallam na Senórach , Irische Texte , Fourth Series , i , l . 3590 ) .
GEARAN AIR A MHNAOI

epithet for his spouse was sgliùrach ,
which would indicate that the domestic atmosphere was not altogether what it might be . As appears from this complaint , her capability as a housewife left something to be desired . This may have been at least partly due to the fact that she suffered from asthma . Her name , according to tradition , was Mary Robertson . She survived her husband .

1303 . lìon :
flax was grown extensively in Uist in MacCodrum ’ s time , and the industry was encouraged by Lady Margaret MacDonald . Cf . l . 1015 n .

1356 . Bhirgìni :
Virginia , the earliest of the American colonies , founded ( after three unsuccessful attempts by Sir Walter Raleigh in the time of Queen Elizabeth ) in 1607 . MacDonalds and MacLeods , and others from the Isles of Skye and Raasay , settled on the York and Rappahannock Rivers in Virginia during the first half of the eighteenth century , and the reference to Virginia may have been specially topical about the time that the song was composed owing to the fact that at the close of the Seven Years ’ War ( 1763 ) many soldiers in Highland regiments who were then disbanded or had completed their terms of service received grants of land in Virginia and the Carolinas ( Celtic Review , vii , 295 ) . When the great exodus from the Highlands began c . 1770 , it was to the Carolinas that most of the emigrants went . Virginia was famous , then as now , for its tobacco , of which the Islanders were fond even as early as 1700 , when they were described by Martin .
AOIR NAN TÀILLEIREAN

Bha MacCodrum a ’ fuireach an Uibhist a ’ Chinn a Tuath , an àite ris an abradh iad Taobh Loch Eubhord [i . e . Langais] . Bha an t - àite anabarrach fada bho dhaoine . Cha bhiodh na tàilleirean deònach a dhol a dh ’ obair ann ; cha bhiodh spòrs gu leòr ann , no dannsa , no dad de ’ n t - seòrsa sin . Bhiodh a bhean a ’ deanamh pìosan clò ; ’ s chaidh e dh ’ iarraidh tàilleir uair no dhà ’ s cha tigeadh iad . Rinn e an sin òran dhaibh , agus an uair a chuala iad an t - òran thug iad bòid nach fuaighleadh iad greim dha ged a bhiodh e falbh rùisgte .

Bhiodh Morair Chlann Domhnaill a ’ tighinn tacan do ’ n dùthaich a h - uile samhradh [foghar] , ’ s bhiodh còisir de dhaoine uaisle eile maille ris . Bhiodh greadhnachas mór ann an latha thigeadh e ; bhiodh móran de ’ n tuath ag cruinneachadh far am bitheadh e , ’ g a mholadh fhéin ’ s a ’ moladh athar ’ s a sheanar . Bha MacCodrum ’ s toil aige bhith ’ n am measg ; bha nàire air a dhol ann cho luideach , ach chaidh e ann is dh ’ fhuirich e ann an imeall na cuideachd . Thug am Morair an aire dha . Dh ’ fharraid e dh ’ an duine bha ri thaobh có an duine bochd a bha siod . Arsa an duine uasal , “ Siod MacCodrum am bàrd ! ” “ Agus ciod e chuir cho luideach e ? ” arsa am Morair . “ Tha , ” arsa esan , “ nach fhaigh e tàilleir a nì car dha . ” “ ’ S cinnteach nach ’ eil e ’ g am pàigheadh , ma ta , ” arsa am Morair . “ Tha , ” arsa an duine uasal , “ ach rinn e òran daibh , ’ s cha tig duine aca thuige . ” “ Abair ris tighinn far a bheil mi , ” arsa am Morair . Thàinig MacCodrum a nuas , ’ s dh ’ fhaighneachd am Morair dheth ciod e chuir cho rùisgte siod e . Dh ’ innis esan nach

fhaigheadh e tàilleir [a chionn ’ s gun do rinn e òran ’ g an càineadh . Dh ’ iarr am Morair air an t - òran a ghabhail , ’ s rinn e siod . ] Thubhairt am Morair ris an duine uasal , “ Thoir thusa dha deise aodaich air mo chosg - sa , ’ s bheir mise dha an t - àite ’ s a bheil e fuireach saor gun mhàl [mar bhàrd . ” Fhuair e a thuilleadh air a sin duais airgid agus cóig bollachan mine ’ s a ’ bhliadhna . An uair a chuala Iain mu dheighinn na mine , thuirt e , “ Gu neartaicheadh Dia sibhse , Thighearn , ’ s math an t - aran , ach b ’ fheàirrd e an t - annlan , ” agus chaidh cóig clachan càise a chur ris a ’ mhin . ]

[Cóig rainn de dh ’ Aoir nan Tàilleirean . ]
( MT . , vii , 14 . )

( MacCodrum was living in North Uist , in a place called Loch Eford Side [i . e . Langash] . The place was exceedingly far from people . The tailors would not be willing to go to work there ; there would not be enough fun there , or dancing , or anything of that kind . His wife used to make pieces of tweed ; and he went for a tailor once or twice and they would not come . He then composed a song to them , and when they heard the song they made a vow that they would not sew a stitch for him though he were to go naked .

The Chief of Clan Donald used to come for a short time to the district every summer [autumn] , and a company of other gentlemen along with him . There used to be a great display the day he came ; many of the tenants used to gather where he was , praising himself and praising his father and his grandfather . MacCodrum was desirous to be among them ; he was ashamed to go so ragged , but he went and stayed on the fringe of the assembly . The Chief noticed him . He asked the man who was beside him what poor man that was . Said the gentleman , “ That is MacCodrum the bard ! ” “ And why is he so ragged ? ” said the Chief . “ Because , ” said he , “ he cannot find a tailor who will do a hand ’ s turn for him . ” “ I suppose he does not pay them , then , ” said the Chief . “ He does , ” said the gentleman , “ but he composed a song to them , and none of them will come to him . ” “ Tell him to come to speak to me , ” said the Chief . MacCodrum came forward , and the Chief asked him why he was as bare as that . He explained that he could not get a tailor [because he had composed a song lampooning them . The Chief asked him to sing the song , and he did that . ] The Chief said to the gentleman ,

“ You give him a suit of clothes at my expense , and I will give him the place where he stays free without rent [as bard . ” He received besides a grant of money and five bolls of meal a year . When John heard about the meal , he said , “ God strengthen you , my lord , bread is good , but it would be the better for condiment , ” and five stones of cheese were added to the meal . ]
[Five verses of the Satire on the Tailors . ] )

According to one account ( MC . , xlvi ) the bard had gone to live in Eaval when the song was composed , but current tradition and indications in one or two other songs agree with Ferguson . It can be proved from Sir James ’ s correspondence that it was not in summer , but in autumn , that he was in the habit of visiting North Uist . The meeting with MacCodrum took place between 6th August and 19th September 1763 , probably in the former month ( see Introduction ) . The term Morair is perhaps not quite appropriate as Sir James ’ s successor was the first of the Sleat family to hold a peerage . The statement that MacCodrum ’ s wife made tweeds is perhaps evidence that there is some exaggeration in his complaint against her
( Gearan air a Mhnaoi )
and in l . 1333 .

1376 . na bàghannan :
numerous smaller inlets branch off from the long length of Loch Eford . MacCodrum probably had in mind those near his home at Langash — Loch Langais , Bàgh Orasaidh , and Ob a ’ Ghibhte .

1385 . nam Mìlidh : mìlidh = ( 1 ) soldier ( Latin miles ) ; ( 2 ) the name of the legendary leader of the Gael when they conquered Ireland . The poet seems to mean : na mìlidhean = the Gaelic warriors with special reference to their descent from Mìlidh . For Mìlidh see BGh . , l . 1652 n . The eighteenth - century tradition on the subject , as given by Iain mac Ailein ,
the Mull bard , appears in the Glenbard Collection ( 76 ff . ) . In a lament by the same bard for Sir John Maclean of Duart which was known to MacCodrum ( see notes on next song ) the following lines occur :

… geugan ro phrìseil
De fhìon - fhuil na Spàinne .
Bha fios aig luchd - leughaidh
’ S aig seanchaidhean geur ’
Air bhur teachd o Ghatélus
As an Eiphit a thàinig ;

Labhair mi ri Lachlann
Air a ’ Chladach ged bha ’ n t - Sàbaid ann ;
’ S ann thuirt e rium gum b ’ fhaide leis
Mac Raibeirt bhith gun tàilleireachd —
“ ’ S e meud do gheall air òsdairean
A dh ’ fhàg do phòca fàs agad ,
A dh ’ fhàg an t - aodach tan ’ agad
’ S cha chuir a ’ bhean ’ n a àite dhuit . ”

1410 . Mac Raibeirt :
who he was is unknown . Robert Ferguson was a tenant in Clachan in 1718 ( Clan Donald , iii , 659 ) . The name Robert is in Uist practically confined to the Fergusons . The tradition is that a Ferguson from the district near Kildrummy Castle accompanied Robert the Bruce to Uist when the latter was a fugitive , received land there , and named his son after the king . But there may be as much knowledge of book history as of tradition in that . Nevertheless it is a fact that there were Fergusons of old in Aberdeenshire .

1415 . Mac - an - t - Saoir :
unless this is a patronymic , the tailor here mentioned was evidently not of old North Uist stock . Tormet McIntyre was a tenant in Baile Mhic Phàil in 1718 ( Clan Donald , iii , 659 ) .

1430 . Càirinis :
a village in the extreme south of North Uist , facing the North Ford . Whether this was the abode of the son of Angus Glas or a place of halt on the way to MacCodrum ’ s home in Langash is not clear .

1431 . Mac - a - Phiocair :
the MacVicars were a family of old standing in North Uist . Towards the end of the sixteenth century Donald MacVicar
( Am Piocair Mór )
and his four sons

occupied some of the best land in the island . Of the sons , Donald had Carinish and Cladach Carinish ; Angus ( known as Aonghus Mhannta ) had Baleloch , Balemartin , and Balelone ; Hector had Kyles Bernera , Baile Mhic Phàil , and Baile Mhic Conain ; and John , the youngest , dwelt with his father , who held Baleshare and Eaval . Their prosperity aroused the envy of Uisdean mac Gill - easbuig Chléirich ,
the villain par excellence of North Uist story , who is on record as ballivus of the island in 1588 . He is said to have murdered the four young MacVicars in cold blood ; their father was away from his home at the time and escaped . Vengeance for this crime is said by some to have been the cause of Hugh ’ s downfall . The widow of Hector MacVicar was particularly fierce in her hatred of him . A waulking - song of which snatches may still be heard sung in Uist is attributed to her :

Him bò - ill ù - ill ò
Hu - o hò - ro éile - na
Him bò - ill ù - ill ò .
Uisdein mhic Gill - easbuig Chléirich
Far an laigh thu slàn na éirich
Do mhionach bhith ’ n luib do léine
Sgeul do bhàis do mhnathan Shléite
Is thugam - sa mo chuid fhéin dheth .

She is said to have helped the party , headed by Domhnall mac Iain mhic Sheumais ,
who arrested Hugh in the vicinity of Dùn an Sticir ,
with encouragement and advice . There are , however , several accounts of the circumstances of Hugh ’ s capture ( Beveridge ’ s North Uist , 142 - 144 , 287 - 288 ) .

The lesser of the Carinish temples is called Teampull Clann a ’ Phiocair .
In 1861 there were ninety - eight persons bearing the name in North Uist ( Proc . Soc . Antiq . Scot . , xi , 505 - 506 ) .
ORAN DO SHIR SEUMAS MACDHOMHNAILL

Nach iongnadh ri chlaistinn
Gu bheil mis ’ o chinn fhada ( cf . l . 1448 )
Ann an turracadaich cadail
Agus m ’ acaid ro chràiteach ;
Tha cnoimh air mo ghiùlan ( cf . l . 1451 ) .
’ S mi leisg air a dùsgadh
Air eagal le bùrach
Gun ùraich i ’ m bàs dhomh .
Gidheadh cha sgeul rùine
Ach sgeul as mór cùram
Sir Iain gun dùsgadh
An dlùthchiste chlàraidh :
B ’ e so ar fras dhùbailt
Mhill ar n - abhall ’ s ar n - ubhlan ,
Rinn ar dosgaidh a chrùnadh
Fhrois am flùr bhàrr a ’ ghàraidh .
( E . , 126 . )
1467 - 1468 . Cf . the chorus of a song composed in 1715 by Iain Dubh mac Iain mhic Ailein :

1473 . ceannard :
Sir Alexander MacDonald , who died in 1746 . He is the subject of ll . 1471 - 1486 . Sir Alexander refused to join in the rising of 1745 and consequently incurred the abuse of certain of the Jacobites , whose opinion of him was pithily expressed in the following lines :

Mac Dhomhnaill gun sgoinn
Chaidh a chomhdach ’ s an fhoill ,
’ N uair bu chòir dha bhith dìleas
’ S ann a dhìbir e ghreim .
( cf . Glenbard Coll . , 126 . )
1505 . The reference is to some card game , but cairt dhùbailt is obscure .

1506 . Ar crùn :
a crowned piece in draughts , also termed crùnair .

1513 - 1514 . In the Roman Catholic Church prayers to God for special favours are often accompanied by some particular form of good works such as giving alms to the poor
( nasgadh déirce do na bochdan ) .
Hence , by association , the present passage practically means “ We are praying earnestly to God that thou mayest return home in safety . ” Nasgadh strictly means pledging or ear - marking in advance what is to be given away as alms .
1546 . The usual phrase is gun taise gun tàire .

1629 . O Chlach :
Cloch Point , at the mouth of the Clyde opposite Dunoon .

1630 . Port Phàdruig :
Port Patrick in Wigtownshire , facing the Irish coast . MacCodrum ’ s knowledge of the geography of the south of Scotland may seem surprising . It is quite possible , however , that he was personally acquainted with the Firth of Clyde . In the eighteenth century Islanders frequently went as far as Glasgow in open boats .

1639 . na Leòdaich :
Sir Alexander MacDonald , father of Sir James , was a son of Janet , daughter of Alexander MacLeod of Greshornish ( Clan Donald , iii , 474 ) . There were also earlier alliances between the Sleat family and the MacLeods , both of Dunvegan and Lewis .

1658 . Sìol Ailein :
the MacDonalds of Clan Ranald , descended from Allan , son of Reginald , son of John Lord of the Isles . The sense would almost seem to imply that the men of Glengarry were among Allan ’ s descendants ; but the MacDonalds of Glengarry trace their descent , not to Allan , but to his younger brother Donald ( Clan Donald , iii , 226 ) .

1671 . fir Mhuile :
the Macleans , particularly perhaps the family of Duart . Donald Gormeson , sixth Chief of Sleat
( Domhnall Gorm Sasannach ) ,
married Mary , daughter of Hector Mór Maclean of Duart ( Clan Donald , iii , 469 ) . MacCodrum was probably thinking of this ancestress when he claimed the House of Duart as one of Sir James ’ s allies .

1683 . nan Duibhneach :
the Campbells , whose descent , in the oldest extant pedigrees , is traced to one Duibhne , whom later genealogists wrongly regarded as a son of Diarmaid , one of the leading figures in the Fionn cycle ( Skene , Celtic Scotland , iii , 459 ) .
TÀLADH IAIN MHÙIDEARTAICH

Air do ’ n bhàrd air latha àraidh tighinn a Uibhist mu Thuath do Bhaile nan Cailleach , mhothaich Mac ’ ic Ailein dha a nuas o ’ n chladh is ghabh e ceum suas ’ n a choinnimh is Iain Mùideartach , is gun e an uair sin ach ’ n a phàisde beag , air làimh aige . [Suas chun a ’ Bhaile Aird ( O . ) ] chuir e bonn òir an làimh Iain Mhùideartaich is dh ’ iarr e air a dhol an coinnimh a ’ bhàird is an t - òr a thoirt da . Rinn am pàisde so . Dh ’ fhaighnich am bàrd dheth an robh tuilleadh òir no airgid aige , is thuirt e nach robh . “ Ma ta , ” arsa am bàrd , “ chan ’ eil oighre fearainn fo ’ n ghréin a bheireadh dhomhsa a chuid dh ’ an t - saoghal ach thu fhéin . ” Thog e am pàisde air a ghualainn is choisich e sìos chun an tighe . ’ S e bun a bh ’ ann cha ghabhte uaithe an gille mur dèanadh e òran dha . Thuirt e gu feuchadh e ri siod a dhèanamh na faigheadh e a dh ’ ùine fhad ’ s a bhiodh e dol timcheall a ’ ghàraidh - chàil . Fhuair e siod . An uair a thàinig e air ais thog e Iain Mùideartach ’ n a uchd is sheinn e dha an t - òran .

1689 . iarogha :
John of Moidart ’ s great - grandfather was Donald MacDonald of Benbecula , on whom devolved the chiefship of Clan Ranald when Ranald , fifteenth Chief , died in 1725 . He died in 1730 , and was buried in the churchyard mentioned above , Cladh Mhoire ,
Nunton ( Clan Donald , iii , 233 - 234 , 279 ) .

1706 . a ’ chruit :
harp playing was not much in evidence by the date of this song . Cf . ll . 999 - 1000 and note .

1708 . do sheanmhar :
John of Moidart ’ s grandmother was Margaret , daughter of William MacLeod of Bernera , eldest son of Sir Norman MacLeod of Bernera and Katherine , daughter of Sir James MacDonald of Sleat . She married Ranald , seventeenth Chief of Clan Ranald , in 1720 , and died at Ormiclate on 20th September 1780 . She was buried at Nunton ( Clan Donald , iii , 234 - 235 ) .

1723 . an t - àrmunn Sléiteach :
in the conventional enumeration of allies MacCodrum first mentions his own patron , Sir James MacDonald , whom he no doubt regarded as head of the whole clan .

1729 . Fir Chnòideart :
the MacDonalds of Knoydart were descended from Allan , second Chief of Clan Ranald . They lost the lands of Knoydart about 1610 ( Clan Donald , iii , 238 - 239 ) . It is possible that members of the family may have preserved their identity as tenants of the tacksman class down to MacCodrum ’ s time .

1737 . Domhnallaich ’ s Raghnallaich :
MacDonalds ( ? of Sleat ) and MacDonalds of Clan Ranald .

1757 . Arla :
Harlaw . The battle of Harlaw is usually termed in Gaelic Cath Gairbheach .
It was fought in 1411 when Donald of the Isles attempted to make good his claim to lands in Aberdeenshire as part of the Earldom of Ross . His opponents consisted of the burgesses of Aberdeen and the men of Angus and the Mearns under the command of the Earl of Mar and the Sheriff of Angus . The battle itself was indecisive . The Islesmen ’ s losses were much less than those of the opposing army but they advanced no farther and Donald withdrew with his men towards the west .

1758 . ’ N uair bhrosnaich Lachlann am bàrd iad :
the bard referred to is Lachlan MacVurich . A Brosnachadh ascribed to him was published in Ranald MacDonald ’ s Collection in 1776 , where it is described as
“ Prosnuchadh - catha roinaidh le Lachun - Moir - Macmhuireach - Albinnich , do Dhomhnil a Iola , Riodh Inshagoill , agus Eairla Rois ; la Machrich Cathgariach , Thugidh è June 11 , 1411 . ”
It begins :

A Chlannaibh Cuinn cuimhnichibh
Cruas an am na h - iorghuille
Gu … etc . , etc .
( E . , 5 . )

1764 . là blàir Léinidh :
the battle of Kinloch Lochy ( 1545 ) , in which the MacDonalds of Clan Ranald under their chief ,

1772 . an Lòchaidh :
the battle of Inverlochy ( 1645 ) , in which Montrose routed the Covenanting army of the Marquis of Argyll .

1773 . Domhnall :
Donald , later thirteenth Chief of Clan Ranald , was present at the battle of Inverlochy as well as his father , John of Moidart , whom he succeeded in 1670 . He died in Canna in 1686 and was buried at Howmore ( Book of Clan Ranald in Rel . Celt . , ii , 183 , 209 ) .

1785 . Coille Chnagaidh :
the battle of Killiecrankie , usually termed in Gaelic Latha Raoin Ruairidh ( cf . l . 1790 ) , fought between the Highland army under James Graham of Claverhouse , Viscount Dundee , and the forces of the Government , in 1689 . The Highlanders won the day , but their leader was killed , and without him the rising soon came to nothing .

1786 . MacAidh :
General Mackay , who was in command of the Government troops . This is an old form of the name still in use in Uist . It is the form used by Aonghus mac Alasdair Ruaidh in his song on the battle of Killiecrankie . Addressing Sir Ewen Cameron , he says :

1792 . Sliabh an t - Siorraim :
the battle of Sheriffmuir , which , though indecisive in itself , resulted in the abandonment by the Earl of Mar and the other Jacobite leaders of the attempt made in 1715 to restore the House of Stuart . The Hanoverian forces were under the command of the Duke of Argyll . The MacDonalds of Clan Ranald fought in the Jacobite army .

1794 . Ailean :
Allan MacDonald , known as Ailean Beag ,
fourteenth Chief of Clan Ranald , who was mortally wounded in the battle . He was taken to Drummond Castle , where he died on the following day . To judge from the number of elegies , bardic and vernacular , and other songs , composed to him , his popularity in the Highlands was immense . It is still told in the Isles that the news of his fall in the battle was first known in Barra , from whence it reached his own lands in Uist . The story is that a certain old man in the village of Borve who had the gift of frìth or divination stood on a knoll all day and described the fight to his neighbours . “ Thuit Mac ’ ic Ailein , ”
said he . “ An do mharbhadh e ? ”
he was asked . “ Chan urrainn mi a ràdh , ach thatar ’ g a ghiùlan a mach as an àraich is fhuil ’ g a dhalladh . ”
It will be remembered that Neil MacVurich heard that he was wounded before the news of his death arrived , and composed a song on receiving each piece of news ( E . , 73 , 75 ) .

Fhir a shiubhlas gu h - eutrom ,
Chan eagal dhuit beud no puthar ,
Is garbhag an t - sléibhe
Bhith air do shiubhal .

Sian roimh shaighead shìdheach ,
Sian roimh ghath shluaghach ,
Sian roimh luaidhe shaoghlach ,
Sian a ’ bheatha bhòrcach bhuan
Roimh shluagh agus roimh bhaoghal .

But there was another woman from Stoneybridge
( Staoinebrig ) ,
a widow , whose only son Clanranald had taken away against her will and despite her threats . His name was Dubh - sìdh , according to present tradition ( perhaps by confusion with the murderer of Maclean of Duart at the battle of Tràigh Ghruinneard ) . “ If

1795 . b ’ fhearail a chruth :
Clanranald derived the sobriquet Ailean Beag from the fact that the breadth of his shoulders made him appear short of stature .
MOLADH CHLANN DOMHNAILL

Moladh Chlann Do ( mh ) nuill Leis ,
M . Moladh Chloinn Donaill , leis an Ian MacCodrum cheudna ,
G .

The song is well known in Uist under the name of Cuideachadh Dhomhnaill mhic Fhionnlaigh .
It appears that a young man of this name came to Uist some time before the date of the song and on one occasion expressed his appreciation of the kindness he received from the Uist people . Regretting that he had not the bardic gift to sing their praises , he said :

There has apparently been some confusion between the story attached to it and the similar story told regarding Oran do Mhac ’ ic Ailein ,
which is given in the notes to that song ( cf . UB . , xxxiii , xxxiv - xxxv ) .

1799 . Who Domhnall mac Fhionnlaigh was it is perhaps impossible to say now . All that is known of him has been mentioned supra . It has been noted ( BGh . , 280 ) that he had the same patronymic as the person mentioned in the Coimhstrith ;
but the latter was not a stranger to Uist ( l . 848 n . ) .

1816 . pòghad :
this word has been suppressed in G . and all subsequent printed versions , but it may be objected that the alternatives put forward do not give the required rime . In M . ( where all English words have been deleted and Gaelic words , usually inferior metrically , written above ) poet has , strangely enough , been allowed to stand . The fact that present - day tradition and the earliest version agree on the matter independently is conclusive . The writer once heard a Uistman comment on the word as follows : Bhiodh m ’ athair ag gabhail an òrain so leam an uair a bha mi beag , agus an uair a thigeadh e chun an fhacail so stadadh e agus theireadh e , “ ’ S a bheil fhios agad ciod e th ’ ann pòbhad ( sic ) ? ” Theirinn - sa nach robh . “ Tha , ma tha , bàrd . ” Agus cha do thuig mi riamh gur e facal Beurla a bh ’ ann gu robh mi treis mhath a ’ dol dh ’ an sgoil .

1856 . Mac Dhomhnaill :
Sir James MacDonald , for whom see notes on Oran do Shir Seumas and Marbhrann do Shir Seumas .

1863 . Mac ’ ic Ailein : Ranald ,
seventeenth Chief of Clan Ranald , who died at Nunton on 6th March 1766 ( Clan Donald , iii , 234 - 235 ) . The chiefs of Clan Ranald were known by this patronymic because of their descent from the son of Allan , son of Ranald or Reginald ( whence Clann Raghnaill ) , son of John , Lord of the Isles .

1870 . abhainn Lòchaidh :
cf . l . 1772 n .
Knoydart and Glenelg , and Loch Nevis between Knoydart and Morar . For Bun na Stuaighe compare Alexander Mackinnon , the Morar bard :

Tighinn gu cala na stuaighe
’ N aodann gaillinn ’ g a cruaidhead
’ S lom a ghearradh tu ’ m fuaradh le sròin .
( Glenbard Coll . , 249 ( 29 ) . )

Tha Clann Mhic Dhubhghaill bho ’ n stuaigh
’ S an coille dhlùth air a buain ;
Bu ghoirt an diùbhail ’ s bu chruaidh an sgeul e .
( Ibid . , 253 ( 33 ) . )

1879 . teaghlach na Ceapaich :
the MacDonalds of Keppoch traced their descent to Alasdair Carrach , fourth son of John , Lord of the Isles . The next line perhaps refers to their losses at Culloden , where Alexander , seventeenth Chief , was killed , or , more probably , to the absence of Ranald , the next chief , in Jamaica , and of his younger brother Alexander in Prince Edward Island . Ranald returned to Keppoch in 1777 , and died there in 1788 ( Clan Donald , iii , 422 - 423 ) .

1883 . Mac Iain :
the patronymic of the chief of the MacDonalds of Glen Coe , who were descended from John , son of Angus Og of Isla .
