It was also the patronymic of the MacDonalds of Ardnamurchan , who were descended from Iain Sprangach , third son of Angus Mór , Lord of the Isles . But they disappeared as a landed family long before the time of the song , and MacCodrum meant the family of Glen Coe ( Clan Donald , 210 , 212 ) .

1887 . Mac Dhubhghaill a Latharn :
the MacDougalls are generally supposed to be of the same stock as the Clan Donald , but the genealogists disagree as to the nature of the relationship — whether the Dubhghall from whom they take their name was a brother or a son or a grandson of Somerled ( Skene , Celtic Scotland , iii , 338 , 470 ; Clan Donald , i , 60 ff . , iii , 179 - 180 ) .

1890 . The MacDonalds had lost their lands in Islay before MacCodrum ’ s time . Sir James MacDonald , the last representative of the MacDonalds of Dùn Naomhaig ( Clann Iain Mhóir )
died in London in 1626 ( Clan Donald , iii , 379 ) .

1891 . Iarla Aondroma :
at the time of the song the head of the MacDonalds of Antrim was Alexander , fifth Earl ( Clan Donald , iii , 415 ) .

1903 . baile ’ s leth Alba :
this phrase often occurs in Gaelic as a conventional mode of describing the major part of a country . Deirdre uses the phrase in her lament for the sons of Uisneach :

Bail ’ agus leth Albainn féin
Do bhiodh agam , àrd an ceum .
( Leabhar na Féinne , 23 , col . 2 . )

Sliochd nan curaidhnean talmhaidh
Leis ’ n do chuireadh Cath Gairbheach ;
Fhuair mi uiread dh ’ ur seanchas
Gun robh ’ n turus ud ainmeil ,
Gun robh tigh is leth Alba fo ’ r cìs .
( E . , 199 . )

Tigh is leth Albainn
Bha siod aig rìgh Fionnghall .
( Songs and Poems , 56 . )

Sliochd nan Collaidhean garga
Leis na chuireadh Cath Gailbheach ,
’ S Domhnall Ballach nan garbhchreach
Rinn Tigh nan Teud aig leth Alba ’ n a chrìch .
( Ibid . , 94 . )
For early references see BGh . ( 281 ) , where it is stated that Tigh nan Teud is “ about two miles north of Pitlochry , on the east side of the road just below Bridge of Garry . ”

Gur càirdeach thu Dhomhnall
Dh ’ an robh còrr is leth Alba fo smachd .
( E . , 355 . )

Gun robh tigh is leth Ile
Am bann daingeann dhuit sgrìobhte ,
’ S bha na fearainn sin strìochdte gu réidh dhuit .
( GB . , i , 56 . )

Go mb ’ fhearra liom bé na gcraobhfholt gcíortha gcas
Ar leaba lem thaobh , nú ar aonach taoibh liom seal ,
Ná baile is leath Éireann ’ s a mbéith le straoille leamh .
( O ’ Rahilly , Búrdúin Bheaga , 17 . )

1905 . latha Chath Gairbheach :
cf . l . 1757 n .

1909 . Mac Gill - Eathain :
at the battle of Harlaw Hector Maclean of Duart led the right wing of the Highland army at the head of his clan . He and Sir Alexander Irvine of Drum fought in single combat until both fell dead ( Clan Donald , i , 156 , 162 ) .

1910 . Lachlann cutach Mac - an - Tòisich :
the left wing at the battle of Harlaw was led by Mackintosh ( Clan Donald , i , 156 ) . But his name was Malcolm .

1917 . Barraich :
cf . Iain Lom :

Chan ’ eil Rothach no Barrach ,
Chan ’ eil Gallach no Tuathach ,
Nach bu dleas da bhith leatsa
’ N am caismeachd na h - uaire .
( Glenbard Coll . , 29 . )
It is clear that the bard does not mean the Barra men as he mentions réisimeid nan Niallach in l . 1929 . See also BGh . , 281 - 282 , and ll . 4052 , 4078 , ibid .
1918 . Cf . Iain Dubh mac Iain mhic Ailein :

Tàilich :
the form Sàilich ,
which occurs in one source , is also used , though less commonly .

1928 . réisimeid nan Leòdach :
cf . l . 1639 n .

1929 . réisimeid nan Niallach :
the MacNeils of Barra . Cf . l . 1917 n . They were a notable seafaring clan . It is possible that they also were claimed as allies in virtue of having received their lands from the MacDonalds , this time with some justification , for Gilleonan , son of Roderick , son of Murdoch MacNeil , received a charter of the lands of Barra from Alexander , Earl of Ross and Lord of the Isles , in 1427 ( MC . , xxxviii ) . And in an old waulking - board flyting between a Barra woman and a Uist woman the latter tauntingly refers to Barra as :

Déirc a fhuair sibh
Bhuainn an asgaidh
’ N uair a chunnaic
Dia ’ n ur n - airc sibh .
( MC . , 235 . )

1932 . Clann Reubhair :
the MacDonalds of Dalness in Glen Etive ( BGh . , 282 ) . Cf . l . 1918 n . One of the prisoners taken by Captain Ferguson during his progress through Uist in the summer of 1746 was Duncan McRievre , Benbecula , “ For having rowed the Pretender ’ s son from S . Uist to Skye ” ( Scottish History Society , The Prisoners of the ’ Forty - five , iii , 184 - 185 ) .

1933 . fir na h - Iubhraich :
i . e . the men of Tomnahurich in Inverness . According to legend , the fairies dwelt there , and MacCodrum may have them in mind . But it is quite probable that he may have been thinking of the Fiann who also , according to one account , were in Tomnahurich ( cf . Gregorson Campbell , The Fians , 3 - 4 ) , and were expected to rise again one day .

1934 . Tòmas :
legend asserted that among the fairy inhabitants of Tomnahurich was Thomas the Rhymer . It was believed that he would reappear among men , and that was to be the signal for a rising in which the true Gaels would crush the power of their enemies , which in the eighteenth century meant the Houses of Hanover and Argyll . For references see BGh . , 282 - 283 . Gregorson Campbell in his Superstitions of the Scottish Highlands ( 271 ) notes that in the Outer Hebrides Tòmas Reumhair or Tòmas Réim was said to be in Tomnahurich , and not in Dunbuck Hill
( Dùn Buic )
near Dunbarton : He gives the following version of MacCodrum ’ s lines :

Dar thigeadh sluagh Tom na h - Iubhraich
Co dh ’ éireadh air tùs ach Tòmas ?
ORAN FIR GHRÌMINIS

The traditional title of the song has been retained , although it appears to be a misnomer . The story is that Angus MacDonald of Griminish ( eighth in descent from Domhnall Hearach ) , who is said to have been disliked by the neighbouring tacksmen owing to his masterful and overbearing disposition , was the victim of a plot concocted by the latter to get rid of him . Arrangements were made for a wholesale emigration to America , and in order to keep up the deception as long as possible an imposing quantity of baggage was transported to the place of embarkation ; but the only baggage which contained anything of value was that of the Goodman of Griminish . The rest contained peats and other articles of a like nature which would give the required bulk and weight . By the time Angus MacDonald discovered what was afoot his preparations were made ; he had given up the tenure of Griminish to his brother Archibald , and his pride would not allow him to turn back . He accordingly sailed for America ( in 1766 ) and took up residence at Crane ’ s Creek , Cumberland Co . , North Carolina . His stay there was short , for in 1771 he was back in Uist , though he never regained possession of Griminish . He lived at Balranald on the lands of his kinsman , Donald MacDonald , and died some time after 1785 ( Clan Donald , iii , 485 - 486 ) .

The song was evidently composed before the pretence of the tacksmen was discovered . It acquired the title Oran Fir Ghrìminis retrospectively in course of tradition owing to the fact that the Goodman of Griminish , as already mentioned , was the only one of the tacksmen who fulfilled his declared intention of leaving the country .

Moch ’ s mi ’ g éirigh
Air bheagan éislein
Air maduinn chéitein
’ S mi ann an Os .

1942 . Innse Gall :
literally Isles of Foreigners , i . e . Norsemen . By this was meant the whole of the Hebrides ( Celtic Place - Names of Scotland , 173 ) .

1969 . a ’ chuibhle :
the wheel of fortune . Cf . the following in an elegy to Alasdair Dubh of Glengarry :

Thionndaidh cuibhl ’ air Clann Domhnaill
’ N treasa conspunn bhith bhuatha .
( SO . , 49 . )

Chuaidh a ’ chuibhle m ’ an cuairt ,
Gun do thionndaidh gu fuachd am blàths .
( E . , 103 . )

2030 . plang :
the plack was two - thirds of a shilling Scots , or 8 / 12d sterling . Cf . An Clàrsair Dall :

Fasan don ’ air ’ s chan fhiù e plang .
( GB . , i , 153 . )
ORAN DO CHAIPTEAN AILEAN CHINNSEBORGH

2117 . Clann Mhic Cùibein :
nothing is known of this clan , though the name appears in the records of the Privy Council . They were perhaps notorious for niggardliness .

Gura mis ’ tha fo sprochd ,
Càch mu t ’ fhearann a ’ trod ,
Is nach suidh thu air cnoc g ’ an réiteach .
( Glenbard Coll . , 137 . )

The Gaels held their assemblies in the open on certain knolls used for the purpose from time immemorial . The idea here is the same as that of the word eireachdail ,
which originally signified “ fit to be seen in an assembly . ” ( Cf . Skene , Celtic Scotland , iii ,

390 - 391 ; Carmina Gadelica , ii , 247 . ) There is a similar idea in the Irish proverb , Dána gach fear go tulaig ,
“ Every man is bold until he is at a public assembly ” ( O ’ Rahilly , A Miscellany of Irish Proverbs , 25 ) .

2157 . far na féille :
like his renowned ancestor , Domhnall mac Iain mhic Sheumais ,
who is reputed to have been the first to ferry cattle between Uist and Skye , Allan MacDonald was a great drover . In that connexion it is told how his continued success in this occupation aroused the jealousy of other drovers in Skye . They picked a quarrel with him in a certain inn when their numbers were sufficient — Allan was a remarkably powerful man — and handled him severely . A young man , who is said in Uist to have left MacDonald ’ s employ after having had a difference with him , heard the news in Edinburgh , and regretted that he had not been at Allan ’ s side to help him when he was attacked . Taking the air and chorus of an older song , Ailein Duinn nach till thu ’ n taobh - sa ,
he composed a song which is still to be heard in the Isles , beginning :

The names of some of the offending drovers are mentioned . One of them was the famous Màrtuinn Mór a ’ Bhealaich ,
who is said to have been Allan MacDonald ’ s chief rival in Skye as a wrestler , and to have finally defeated him owing to his advancing years , Martin being much the younger man . It is stated that the threats contained in the song were carried out at the next fair , which the author attended for that purpose .

2158 . Do chéile :
Flora MacDonald ; the line apparently refers to her health .

2159 . loinn mhic Iain :
the line of Domhnall mac Iain mhic Sheumais ,
who was Allan ’ s great - great - grandfather . The founder of this branch of the MacDonalds was Donald ’ s grandfather , James MacDonald of Castle Camus
( Seumas a ’ Chaisteil ) ,
son of Domhnall Gruamach ,
Chief of Sleat ( Clan Donald , iii , 499 ) .

2175 ff . MacCodrum was probably thinking particularly of Domhnall mac Iain mhic Sheumais ( cf . l . 2159 n ) , who was a famous warrior and the hero of the battle of Carinish , in which a body of MacLeods who invaded North Uist in 1601 was cut off almost to a man . One of the best known of Uist waulking - songs was composed to him by his foster - mother , Nic Còiseam .
His exploits are well known in Uist and Skye , and have appeared in various publications .

Fhionnghail chaomh choibhneil
’ S tu sgàthan gach maighdinn
’ S an reul iuil tha toirt soillse dhaibh
Dh ’ oidhche ’ s a lò ;
De Chlann Domhnaill da - rìribh
An rìbhinn ghlan òg ,
’ S gur àilleagan ciatach
An rìbhinn ghlan òg .
( Celtic Magazine , i , 308 . )

2195 . Aonghus Og :
Angus MacDonald , first of the family of Milton , and Flora ’ s grandfather . He received the tack of Milton from John , twelfth Chief of Clan Ranald . His wife was Mary , daughter of Maclean of Boreray ( Clan Donald , iii , 279 - 280 ) .

2196 . Raghnall Mór :
Ranald MacDonald , first of Benbecula , and Flora ’ s great - grandfather . He was the fourth son of Allan , ninth Chief of Clan Ranald , and was known in his day as Raghnall mac Ailein mhic Iain .
He died in Canna in 1636 and was buried at Howmore ( Clan Donald , iii , 277 - 278 ) .
MARBHRANN DO SHIR SEUMAS MACDHOMHNAILL

2217 . dà fhichead :
between 1695 and 1746 the Sleat family lost five chiefs ; and the same number between 1718 and 1766 . MacCodrum ’ s figure seems to be an approximate reference to the former period , for Sir James ’ s death is mentioned as an added misfortune in l . 2219 .

2235 . an uiridh :
it was probably the beginning of 1767 before the news of Sir James ’ s death reached North Uist .

2249 . nighean Ionnsa :
one of the persons whose incredulity and contempt Ossian had to suffer in his old age . There is a poem called
“ Ninghin Iunnsa ”
in M . ( No . 109 ) of which a version entitled
“ Suireadh Oisein air Eamhair aluinn ”
appears in G . ( 11 ) . The reminiscences of the aged bard are addressed to her :

2252 . According to tradition Ossian lived on long after the rest of the Fiann and survived to see the advent of St Patrick . Some of the Ossianic ballads take the form of dialogues between the two . Oisean an déidh na Féinne is a well - known proverb . It is also current in Ireland
( Oisín d ’ éis na Féine ) .
References to the tradition are common in the literature of both countries . MacCodrum expresses the parallel metaphorically in M . Editors of the later texts rendered it as a simile . The metaphor is more

2270 . Rìgh Dàïdh :
v . l . 2261 n .

2305 . rìgh Seòras :
George III .

2315 . Lùdhais na Frainge :
Louis XV ( 1715 - 1774 ) . Sir James was a prominent figure at his court when he stayed in Paris during his grand tour .

am Pàpa :
the pope at the time was Clement XIII ( 1758 - 1769 ) . Though Sir James was a Protestant , the Pope sent to enquire for him every day during his last illness in Rome .

2318 . Fionn : Fionn mac Cumhaill ,
leader of the Fiann , and hero of the later cycle of heroic tales and ballads . Cf . l . 1005 n . For modern Island tradition regarding him see Gregorson Campbell , The Fians , 16 - 28 .

2319 . Osgar :
son of Ossian and grandson of Fionn . Regarded as the best warrior of the Fiann
( ceud làmh fheum na Féinne ) .
For modern Island tradition see Gregorson Campbell , loc . cit . , 29 - 48 . Laoidh Osgair is one of the best known of Ossianic pieces .

2324 . ùghdar :
this word seems to connote something more than oral tradition . If MacCodrum could not read written histories like the Books of Clan Ranald for himself , it seems likely that he frequented the society of those , like Neil MacVurich , who could and did . This Neil MacVurich ( mentioned in l . 2560 ) learnt to read and write history and poetry from his uncle , Donald MacVurich . His son was illiterate ( Rosg Gàidhlig , 139 - 141 ) .

2326 . Maol - Ciarain :
the author of a poem lamenting his son , a young bard named Fearchar , who visited Ireland to make a

cuairt and was slain there . A Scottish version of the poem is printed in Reliquiæ Celticæ ( ii , 332 ) . It was probably known to MacCodrum ( cf . l . 629a n ) . Maol - Ciarain is often mentioned in a similar context by the bards , e . g . Iain mac Thearlaich Oig :

2333 . na bràithrean :
Alexander , who succeeded Sir James , and who was raised to the peerage in 1776 , and Archibald , who became Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer , and from whom is descended the family of East Sheen ( Clan Donald , iii , 475 ) .
ORAN DO ’ N TEASAICH

Oran a roinnidh don Teasich , air fonn Dàbhi groisgach crom ciar ,
E . Oran Teasaich le Ioin M ‘ Codrum ,
CC .

2372 . The bard is thinking of an oar , of which the blade is liagh and the rounded part lunn .
His emaciated legs would resemble the former rather than the latter .

2383 . How he was wearing both a boineid and a currac at the same time seems difficult to understand unless the currac was in the nature of a biretta to cover his baldness . Rob Donn has a song about a bald man with the chorus :

Gaol currac , gràdh currac ,
Gaol currac , currac mhaol .

Thog na nigheanan collection
A chur deis ’ air Iain maol ;
’ S gur h - e na rinn an t - airgead uile
Gruag is currac agus cìr .
( Morrison , Songs and Poems of Rob Donn , 329 . )
ORAN DO MHAC ’ IC AILEIN

Oran do Mhac Mhic Ailein , ann an Eiric orain Iain Ghrudair ,
S . Oran do Mhac - ic - Ailein no Cuideachadh Iain Ghrudair ,
UB . The latter is a shorter independent version , and that MacCodrum was the author is quite certain .

The tradition is that an individual of somewhat unbalanced mind known as Iain Grùdair ,
who harboured among other delusions an unshakable belief in his own poetic ability , strung together some miserable rambling verses in praise of Clanranald , and repeated them in a certain house in Uist when the bard , lying half - asleep on a bench , was among the company present . When Iain Grùdair ’ s effusion came to an end , MacCodrum roused himself and sang this song .

2400 . Aisling caillich mar a dùrachd is a proverb . It is also known in Ireland , one form being Aisling na caillídhe mar budh sáimh le féin ,
and the wish has been expressed in verse as follows :

Iarraim mo bheith óg arís ,
iarraim ar Chríost mo bheith deas ,
iarraim na hiomairí do - chíd
óigfhir im aghaidh do dhul as .

2414 . an tighearna òg :
the subject of the song was Ranald MacDonald , eighteenth Chief of Clan Ranald , who had shortly before the date of the song succeeded to the dignity , on the death of his father , which took place on 6th March 1766 ( Clan Donald , iii , 235 ) . He was the father of Iain Mùideartach to whom the Tàladh was composed .

2429 . o Eirinn :
the Clan Donald was numerous in Ireland , the best known family being that of Antrim ( Clan Donald , iii , 199 , 202 , 408 ) .

2438 . do chinneadh féin :
the MacDonalds of Clan Ranald .

2446 . Clann Domhnaill :
here apparently used to denote the MacDonalds of Sleat .

2454 . fir Chnòideart :
cf . l . 1729 n .

2462 . Clann Iain :
cf . l . 1883 n .

2470 . na Ceapaich :
cf . l . 1879 n .

2478 . Clann Donnchaidh :
the Robertsons . Agnes , daughter of Ranald Bane , fifth Chief of Clan Ranald ( died 1509 ) , married Robert Robertson of Struan ( Clan Donald , iii , 229 ) . This ( and ll . 2486 ff . , 2494 , 2502 ) gives an indication of MacCodrum ’ s knowledge of Clan Ranald genealogy .

2494 . na Leòdaich :
Ranald Bane , fifth Chief of Clan Ranald , is said to have married a daughter of Roderick MacLeod of Lewis , probably as his second wife . John , twelfth Chief , married ( 1613 ) Marion , daughter of Sir Rory Mór MacLeod of Dunvegan . The mother of the chief celebrated in the song was Margaret , daughter of William MacLeod of Bernera , son of Sir Norman MacLeod of Bernera ( Clan Donald , iii , 229 , 232 , 234 ) .

2502 . na h - Ailpeinich :
several clans — MacGregors , Grants , Mackinnons , MacAulays of Ardincaple , MacQuarries , Macnabs — claimed descent from Kenneth MacAlpin . In this case the reference is to the fact that the subject of the song married in June 1759 , as his second wife , Flora , daughter of John Mackinnon , younger of Mackinnon ( Clan Donald , iii , 235 ) .

na Catanaich ,
the reading in UB . , could be defended on genealogical grounds . Roderick , third Chief of Clan Ranald , married as his second wife Marion , daughter of William Mackintosh , Captain of Clan Chattan . Ranald Bane , fifth Chief , married Catherine , daughter of Lachlan Mackintosh of Gellovie ( Clan Donald , iii , 227 , 229 ) .
MARBHRANN DO CHAIPTEAN FEARGHUSTAN
2511 . An Cuan Sgì is the Little Minch between Skye and Uist . See Watson , Celtic Place - Names of Scotland , 39 .
2517 . Cf . Joshua xxiii , 13 , “ … bithidh iad dhuibh … ’ n am bioraibh ’ n ur sùilibh . ”

2518 . Ruaidheabhal :
there are two hills of this name in Uist . One ( 406 ft . ) is the highest point in Benbecula ; the other ( 286 ft . ) is situated east of Drimore in South Uist . The former is probably intended here .

2521 . Iònah :
see Jonah i , 17 - ii , 10 .

2534 . an tìr ud thall :
possibly Eigg and Canna , where Ferguson ’ s outrages were seen at their worst . Alexander MacDonald , the bard , sent an account of the matter to Bishop Forbes ( Lyon in Mourning , iii , 84 ) .

2536 . Cruachan Beann :
the famous mountain ( 3611 ft . ) in Argyll , near the north end of Loch Awe . Literally , “ Cruachan of Peaks ” ; it has five peaks . Cf . Watson , Scottish Verse from the Book of the Dean of Lismore , xxvii .

2538 . Eubhal :
the highest peak ( 1138 ft . ) in North Uist , situated in the south - east corner of the island . In its shadow MacCodrum spent his latter days .

2542 . Teach an Triubhais :
now known as Beinn Chorghadail ( 1723 ft . ) . Its older name is accounted for by the ridges which jut out in a south - easterly direction , called Cas bho Thuath and Cas bho Dheas .
An old Uist rime says :

Géideabhal is Teach an Triubhais
Dà bheinn as àirde ’ n Uibhist .
Càit ’ an d ’ fhàg thu Heacla bhuidhe ?
Fàgaidh mi i cuide riutha .

Géideabhal also has gone out of use ; the mountain in question now has the much less interesting name A ’ Bheinn Mhór .
It is the highest peak ( 2034 ft . ) in Uist , lying on the south side of Teach an Triubhais . Hecla , on the north side , is the second highest ( 1988 ft . ) .

2546 . Lì bho Dheas :
cf . l . 758 n . There is a very deep loch on the summit of this hill in what looks like the crater of an extinct volcano . A local rime , quoted by Dr Carmichael ( Carmina Gadelica , ii , 299 ) says :

Loch Foghail sin ’ s Loch Foghail
Loch as doimhne fo ’ n domhain :
Ach tha seachd doimhne Loch Foghail
An lochan dubh domhain Lì .

2550 . Beinn MhicMhuirich :
its position is doubtful . It is most probably another name , whether older or not , for Beinn an Tairbeart ( 549 ft . ) near the head of Loch Skiport . This at all events is the view of well - informed residents in the vicinity , who say that the hill was part of the out - run of Stilligarry when the lands were occupied by the MacVurichs .

2554 . shìos ud :
i . e . in Stilligarry .

2555 . Luchd dhèanamh nan dàn :
i . e . the MacVurichs , who had occupied the position of historians to the family of Clan Ranald since the fall of the Lordship of the Isles . They claimed descent from Muireadhach Albanach O Dálaigh ,
a bard who flourished in the thirteenth century , and whose more immediate descendants were bards to the Lords of the Isles . After coming

to Uist they held Stilligarry and the four pennies of Drimsdale in virtue of their office . Tradition says that the grant was a verbal one , and that its terms ( which are of a similar nature to those quoted for the MacQueens in l . 716 n . ) were binding until one of the family was tricked into declaring at the Mercat Cross of Edinburgh , “ Is mise MacMhuirich a mach a Staghlaigearraidh . ”
They lost their office and lands in MacCodrum ’ s time ( cf . l . 2560 n . ) . The family possessed a large number of manuscripts , of which the Black Book and the so - called Red Book of Clan Ranald and some fragments in the National Library of Scotland are still extant . Tradition refers to one member of the family as MacMhuirich Mór and attributes to him supernatural powers , several instances of which are related ( Rel . Celt . , ii , 138 ff . ; Highland Society Report , Appendix , 276 ; Rosg Gàidhlig , 139 - 141 ) .

2558 . Niall Mór :
son of Lachlan and grandson of Donald MacVurich . He was bard to the Clan Ranald family at the beginning of the seventeenth century . There are two poems by him in the Red Book of Clan Ranald , one of them being in praise of the hospitality of Sir Rory Mór MacLeod . It is told in the Isles how , while being lavishly entertained at Dunvegan , MacLeod ’ s bard ( O Muirgheasa ? ) , leading a leash of dogs , found MacVurich in a sorry state overcome by his potations and said :

Tha ’ m bàrd Uibhisteach gu tinn ,
’ S e air a dhruim an tigh an òil ,
’ S ge b ’ e a thug dha an deoch
Thug e lòn do choin Mhic Leoid .

Thug thu alladh air Mac Leoid ,
’ S dhomhsa cha bu chòir a chleith ,
Nach fhaigh a chuid chon de lòn
Ach na nì luchd an òil a sgeith .

2559 . Domhnall Geàrr :
son of Lachlan MacVurich and grandson of Niall Mór just mentioned . In 1633 he received a wadset of the lands of Balmeanach and Gerihorornish in South Uist from

Niall :
son of the foregoing . He was the author of the part of the Red Book of Clan Ranald which deals with the Montrose wars and subsequent events . His early recollections went back to the reign of Charles I . He was a very old man at the time of the rising of 1715 and composed two songs in the vernacular on the wounding and death of Allan MacDonald of Clan Ranald in that year . There are several poems by him in the bardic style in the Red Book of Clan Ranald ( Highland Society Report , Appendix , 276 ; Rosg Gàidhlig , 139 - 141 ; E . , 73 , 75 ; Rel . Celt . , ii , 244 , 248 , 264 , 286 , ? 295 , ? 297 ) .

2560 . Domhnall eile :
son of the foregoing . He seems to have taken over the lands of the family during his father ’ s lifetime , and it was evidently in his time that they ceased to be held entirely rent free , for in 1707 in a tack of Stilligarry and Drimsdale from Allan MacDonald of Clan Ranald to Donald MacVurich , “ indoweller in Stelligarry , ” a rent of £10 Scots was exacted . He was living in 1722 and probably considerably later . He may be regarded as the last of the MacVurich bards . There are two poems in the Red Book of Clan Ranald which may be by him ( Highland Society Report , Appendix , 276 ; Rosg Gàidhlig , 139 - 141 ; Rel . Celt . , ii , 274 , 281 ) .

Niall :
son of Lachlan , brother of the foregoing . He learned to read and write the Irish character from his uncle , but is described as not a “ man of any note . ” It was he who in 1760 gave to James MacPherson the book the identity of which has caused so much controversy . He saw the total abandonment of the office of his ancestors after 1745 , but received a small life pension of £33 , 6s . 8d . Scots from Clanranald ( the Clan Donald evidently confuses him with his son Lachlan ) . It is very probable that MacCodrum knew him and derived some of his literary and historical knowledge from him , if not also from his uncle . The next line ( 2561 ) is apparently an indirect allusion to MacCodrum ’ s own appreciation of their lore ( Highland Society Report , Appendix , 276 ; Rosg Gàidhlig , 139 - 141 ; Rel . Celt . , ii , 140 ; Clan Donald , iii , 123 ) .
BANAIS MHICASGAILL

regarded as pertaining to the regions of Harris and Skye . It would seem probable , in view of this fact , that it was the same wedding which was attended without invitation by Angus Smith
( Aonghus mac Caluim ) ,
nicknamed Am Fuamhair ,
the butt of Archibald MacDonald
( Gille na Ciotaig ) .
Angus suffered the customary penalty for his breach of convention , and Gille na Ciotaig , who may or may not have been at the wedding himself , composed a song upon his discomfiture in which he makes him say :

If this identification is correct , then it is possible that MacCodrum attended a wedding so far from home in virtue of a relationship between his wife , Mary Robertson , and the bride , whose mother apparently it is who is referred to in the song just quoted as Nic Rob .
Robertson is another name uncommon in Uist and the families who bear it are related to each other . MacCodrum ’ s song was composed upon his return home after an absence more prolonged than his wife thought strictly necessary ( UB . , 147 - 149 ; MC . , xxii - xxiii ) .

2568 . an Gleann :
i . e . Glen Ushinish . At the head of the Glen , between Hecla and Teach an Triubhais , is Loch Corodale . The unbidden guest at the wedding , Aonghus mac Caluim ,
who lived according to MC . at Beul na h - Uamha ( ? Maoladh na h - Uamha )
in the Benmore district , is referred to in the song by Gille na Ciotaig as Fuamhair a ’ Ghlinne .
At that time ninety families dwelt in Glen Ushinish . When South Uist was sold to an alien proprietor they were all swept away to make room for sheep . The only habitation now is a shepherd ’ s cottage .

2579 . Buntàta :
South Uist is said to have been the first part of the Highlands in which potatoes were grown . Ranald MacDonald of Clan Ranald saw the root in Ireland while visiting his kinsman , Alexander , fifth Earl of Antrim , and brought back a shipload to Uist , which he ordered his tenants to plant . Only after being

2592 . Mac ’ ic Ailein :
either Ranald , seventeenth Chief of Clan Ranald , or Ranald , eighteenth Chief ; probably the latter . Clanranald ’ s health would no doubt be drunk after the King ’ s as he was the local proprietor .

2592 - 2593 . an t - àrmunn Dubhghlasach :
Archibald James Edward Douglas ( formerly Stewart ) , son of Colonel ( later Sir ) John Stewart of Grandtully , Bart . , and Lady Jane Douglas . Lady Jane had married unknown to her brother , the first Duke of Douglas , and her son was born in Paris on 10th July 1748 , while she and her husband were travelling on the continent . On the death of the Duke in 1761 the tutors appointed by him immediately had his nephew served heir to the estates . The services were unsuccessfully disputed by the Duke of Hamilton , the heir - male , who alleged that Douglas was a supposititious child . The result was the famous “ Douglas Cause , ” which began in the Court of Session in 1762 and lasted until 15th July 1767 , when the Duke of Hamilton won by the casting vote of the Lord President , Robert Dundas of Arniston . The judgment was so unpopular that the Lord President ’ s life was for a time in danger . Douglas appealed to the House of Lords and obtained a reversal of the decision in February 1769 . This was the signal for wild jubilation and tumultuous uproar all over Scotland , for the case had from the first attracted widespread interest , which grew in intensity as the legal struggle was drawn out to such inordinate length . In Edinburgh a mob collected and clamoured for a special illumination in honour of Douglas ’ s victory . Shouting “ Douglas for ever , ” they broke the windows of Dundas , and of Miller , the Lord Justice Clerk , and attempted to break into their houses . Similar attentions were paid to the houses of the Duke of Hamilton ’ s friends and of those who refused to illuminate their windows . This lasted for two nights , and the military had to be called out before order was restored . From MacCodrum ’ s allusion it would appear that enthusiasm for Douglas ’ s cause spread even as far as

2604 - 2605 . an ruidhle dhùbailte :
the eightsome reel .

2615 . an Gleann :
cf . l . 2568 n .

2622 . Coire na h - Eitigh :
this corrie is situated on the north side of Hecla . MacCodrum apparently had an acquaintance there with whom he tarried on the way home . The name is now usually pronounced Coire na h - Eitich ( éiteach = the roots of burnt heather ) . The earlier form of the genitive appears in the song .

2635 . fear a ’ chinn léith :
at the time of the song MacCodrum must have been about seventy - five years old .
BEANNACHADH - TIGHE FIR BHAGHASDAIL

2642 . an t - àrmunn :
Alexander MacDonald of Boisdale , father of Colin . Alexander was the son , by his second marriage , of Donald MacDonald of Benbecula , afterwards sixteenth Chief of Clan Ranald ( cf . l . 2648 ) , and was born in 1698 . In 1745 he refused to join the Prince , but helped him later on when he was a fugitive in the Isles . He fell under suspicion , and was arrested . The Presbytery of Uist drew up a declaration testifying to his loyalty , and that effected his release . Boisdale was a man of great physical strength , and was , according to Hugh MacDonald of Baleshare , “ as able a boulman as any in Scotland . ” He amassed considerable wealth , chiefly in the cattle trade . To tradition he is known as Alasdair Mór nam Mart ,
and many stories are told in which he figures . He is said , for example , once to have sought the hand of the daughter of MacLeod of Dunvegan in marriage .

The lady ’ s two maids , so the story goes , seeing Boisdale ’ s boat approaching , and fearing that if his mission were successful their services would no longer be required , went to meet the voyagers in the guise of crows ( cf . the stories of Iain Garbh Mac Gille - Chaluim of Raasay ’ s death ) with the intention of drowning them . It transpired , however , that Boisdale ’ s helmsman was Lachlan MacVurich , and the MacVurichs are credited in story with the power of counteracting the sgoil dubh at every turn . And so , to the continual croak of the one witch , “ Bàdh Alasdair nam Mart ! Bàdh Alasdair nam Mart ! ”
the other could only say :

2679 . Cailean :
Colin MacDonald of Boisdale , the builder of the house , whose praise begins here . Like his father , he was a man of great business acumen , and enlarged the family fortune considerably . His prosperity is indicated by the fact that he purchased the estate of Ulva and other lands in Mull . He was married twice , first , to Margaret , daughter of Donald Campbell of Airds , and , secondly , to Isabella , daughter of Lieut . Robert Campbell , of the 99th Regiment , afterwards of Glenfalloch , and sister of John , sixth Earl of Breadalbane . Colin MacDonald of Boisdale died on 31st July 1800 ( Clan Donald , iii , 294 - 297 ) .
MARBHRANN DO UISDEAN A ’ BHAILE SHEAR

Hugh MacDonald of Baleshare , the subject of this elegy , was one of the leading men of North Uist in his day . He was the eldest son of Ranald MacDonald , who became tacksman of Baleshare early in the eighteenth century , and who was factor for North Uist before Ewen MacDonald of Vallay . Hugh succeeded to Baleshare on his father ’ s death in 1742 . Rev . Allan MacQueen , in the Old Statistical Account , credits him with the introduction of kelp - making in North Uist . According to this account one Rory MacDonald came to Uist from Ireland at Hugh ’ s invitation . Because this individual ’ s first experiments were unsuccessful and only resulted in the reduction of the seaware to ashes , the local inhabitants , always inclined to take any opportunity of ridiculing new ideas , conferred upon him the sobriquet of Ruairidh na Luatha .
This occurred in 1735 , and it seems possible , therefore , that Rory ’ s sponsor was not Hugh but his father . ( It may be noted that the Clan Donald puts the beginning of kelp manufacture in North Uist as early as 1726 . ) Though he was of Jacobite sympathies , Hugh MacDonald did not join the Prince in 1745 . He was actually in command of a company of Militia , stationed at Kyleakin , while the rising was in progress . After Culloden he secretly took up the Prince ’ s cause , and was able to assist him in various ways , acting as an intermediary between him and Lady Margaret MacDonald . On 10th June 1746 , he and Alexander MacDonald of Boisdale were among those who visited Charles Edward in his but at Corodale to enjoy the society of the Prince over the flowing bowl for three days and three nights . Hugh MacDonald was later one of the correspondents of Bishop Forbes , and sent him an account of the Prince ’ s sojourn in Uist . His death , at the age of sixty - three , took place in 1769 , as MacCodrum mentions in the dating verse of his elegy ( ll . 2759 - 2762 ) . He was buried at Kilmuir . Over his grave is a table - stone , measuring nearly 7 feet long by 4 feet wide , supported upon pillars and bearing “ various devices in relief , the most important of these being a shield charged with the arms of MacDonald of Sleat — quarterly : 1 , a lion rampant ; 2 , a hand in armour , holding a cross - crosslet fitchée ; 3 , a lymphad ( or galley ) sails unfurled and oars in action ; 4 , a salmon naiant ; — while lower down is a group of conventional emblems including a coffin and skull , an hour - glass , cross - bones , shovels , and scythes . Round the edge of this table - stone , and almost immediately below

the shield , are traces of an incised inscription , now undecipherable … ” ( Old Stat . Acc . , xiii , 305 ; Clan Donald , iii , 142 , 538 ; Lyon in Mourning , ii , 94 ; MC . , xxi - xxii ; Beveridge , North Uist , 294 ) .

2691 . Sìol Chuinn :
the MacDonalds claim descent from Conn Ceudchathach ( Conn of the Hundred Battles ) whose name was handed down in the early Irish poetry and traditions , but of whom nothing certain is known . According to the Annals of the Four Masters ( seventeenth century ) his period was the early part of the second century . The term Sìol Chuinn is common in bardic verse .

2704 . Fear Bhàlaidh ’ s a mhac :
Ewen MacDonald of Vallay ( v . l . 869 n . ) and his son , William , who was married to Mary , daughter of Alexander MacDonald of Boisdale ( v . l . 2642 n . ) , with issue , including Alexander , his successor , and Mary , who married Rev . Allan MacQueen ( v . l . 2794 n . ) ( Clan Donald , iii , 543 ) .

2705 . Fear an Uird :
his name , according to the next line , was Archibald . This does not seem to fit any tenant of Ord in Skye who died at the same time as the two MacDonalds of Vallay ; and it is difficult to see in any case why MacCodrum should refer to a member of the clan from Skye in this context . It seems highly probable that the reading in M . is here at fault and that what MacCodrum actually said was Fear an Dùin ,
which fits the case exactly . Archibald MacDonald — eldest son of Rev . Angus MacDonald
( Am Ministeir Làidir ) ,
third son of John MacDonald
( Iain mac Uisdein ) ,
fifth in descent from Domhnall Hearach — lived at Dunskellar
( An Dùn ) ,
and died without issue in 1767 . He had been for some years factor for North Uist . The date of his death fits MacCodrum ’ s verse , which speaks of deaths which took place within six months of that of Sir James MacDonald , or possibly within six months of the receiving of the news in Uist ( Clan Donald , iii , 484 ) .

2708 . Iain :
probably John MacDonald of Kirkibost ( cf . l . 1220 n . ) .

am Bàillidh :
Alexander MacDonald of Balranald ( see notes on Marbhrann do Alasdair mac Dhomhnaill ) .

O bhroilleach Chloinn Domhnaill
D ’ am bu chòir an làmh dhearg .
( Songs and Poems , 70 . )

2722 . Iarla Dhùn Tuilm :
Hugh MacDonald ’ s father was a natural son of Sir James Mór , second baronet of Sleat . The title Iarla is no doubt an echo of the title of Earl of Ross which the Lords of the Isles once held . Rev . Allan MacQueen mentions in the Old Statistical Account ( xiii , 309 ) that the family of Sleat were regarded as the representatives of the old Earls of Ross . The style Iarla Ile was also applied to them by the bards . In a song to Domhnall Gorm Og Iain Lom has the verse :

Aig ogh ’ Iarl ’ Il ’
Agus Chinn - tìre
Rois is Innse Gall .
( E . , 172 . )
2738 . Cf . the proverb , An teanga leam - leat na earb aisd ’ .
MARBHRANN DO NIALL MACGILL - EATHAIN

2779 . Maighstir :
this designation of a layman seems unusual ; perhaps it was in virtue of his being a merchant . It was generally applied to ministers who were as a rule strictly entitled to it as holders of the degree Magister Actium . At the present time it seems to be out of use among Protestant denominations except in the case of the parish minister of North Uist . ( Cf . Naidheachd XV , n . )
FÀILTE DO ’ N CHLÉIR

2793 . an t - athair :
Rev . Donald MacQueen . See l . 863 n .

2795 . trioblaid :
Mr Edmund MacQueen , minister of Barra , and brother of the foregoing , complains of the difficulty of attending Presbytery meetings ( Old Stat . Acc . , xiii , 339 ) .

2801 . mòisean :
perhaps the motion to constitute the meeting .

2802 . a ’ bheinn :
so written , the meaning is simply that he had to betake himself to the moor ; the expression is common in Uist . Tradition , however , glosses this line : Aig an am so bha MacCodrum a ’ fuireach ann an àite ris an abradh iad A ’ Bheinn ,
apparently Eaval , where MacCodrum was living in 1770 .
ORAN DO NA FÒGARRAICH

The above is printed in such a way as to give the impression that MacCodrum is ( merely ) the author of the song to the air of which this is sung , as is the case . The song is ascribed to MacCodrum in UB . , and also by present tradition . The emigration which the bard deplores took place during the few years which preceded the outbreak of the American War . About 1770 there was a marked rise in rents all over the Highlands . The rents of North Uist , for example , were £1200 in 1763 ; in 1771 they amounted to £1800 , and the rise was not entirely compensated by the rising price of kelp and farm produce . The change took place in 1769 , in which year Sir Alexander MacDonald renewed the tacksmen ’ s leases for nineteen years . The result of higher rents was emigration on an extensive scale . Sir Alexander ’ s tacksmen formed themselves into a kind of company , and bought 100 , 000 acres of land in South Carolina , to which they emigrated en masse , taking many of their sub - tenants with them . Altogether , over two hundred people left North Uist between 1771 and 1775 . Great numbers also left the MacDonald estates in Skye , including Flora MacDonald and her husband , Allan MacDonald of Kingsburgh . There was a similar exodus from the Clan Ranald lands of Benbecula and South Uist . The total number who left various estates in the West Highlands at the time ran into thousands . The following may be cited as an example : “ In the year 1769 when Lord MacDonald made a general sett of his estate in Uist and imposed considerable augmentations on his tenants , the farm of Hosta was sett in tack for 19 years from Whit . 1771 , to Hugh Macdonald and John Maclean , the then possessors , at the yearly rent of £24 sterling ; but soon finding themselves unable to continue their possession , they sold off their whole stock , abandoned their farm , and emigrated to America , with many more of his Lordship ’ s tenants who were reduced to similar circumstances , at Whitsunday , 1773 . In this situation Mr Neill Maclean , factor on the Island of Uist , communicated the proceedings of the tenants to Lord Macdonald . … ” This emigration was a voluntary one on the part of comparatively prosperous farmers who had become discontented with their conditions of tenure , but it led to the forced emigration of poorer classes of the community who were much less capable of fending for them -

2810 . ur càirdean :
Rev . Allan MacQueen mentions as one of the reasons for the emigrations from North Uist between 1771 and 1775 the fact that the people received letters from friends who had emigrated several years before giving flattering accounts of North Carolina ( Old Stat . Acc . , xiii , 317 ) .

2835 . Mac Dhomhnaill :
Sir Alexander MacDonald , ninth baronet of Sleat . He lacked his predecessor ’ s Gaelic outlook and could therefore be hardly as popular , but he was an efficient landlord from a business point of view . John Lanne Buchanan describes his policy towards his tenants as follows : “ His Lordship has reversed the œconomy of his kinsman , Clanronald ; for instead of dismissing the actual cultivators of the land , he has taken them under his own immediate protection , and settled them by dozens , in the room of one over - grown land - broker , or tacksman . Yet it is justice to mention , that Lord Macdonald did not expel the tacksmen , but only reduced their immoderate farms . His Lordship has been subjected to much unmerited obloquy . His tenants , according to their station , and in comparison of the sub - tenants of tacksmen , lived in a state of affluence . It is also to be observed , that although , on the whole , his Lordship chuses to multiply industrious and contented husbandmen , rather than to support idle gentlemen , he has been known , in the choice of tenants , to give a preference to gentlemen of active turns already settled on his estate , before others , who made larger and more tempting offers for their farms . He is very attentive to the equal and prompt distribution of justice among his tenants . ” A less favourable impression of his policy is to be derived from other sources .

Cha dèan cearcan fraoich no naoisg e
Tha ’ n an laigh ’ air aodann fàsaich ,
Cha dèan féidh le ’ n cabair chaola ,
Cha dèan caoirich mhaola bhàn ’ e :
Cuiribh iadsan fo ’ n cuid fhaobhar ,
Leigibh iad gu aodann nàmhaid ,
Feuch an toir iad buaidh ’ s a ’ Ghearmailt ,
Feuch an dearbh iad an làmh - làidir .
NAIDHEACHDAN

A large number of stories in which MacCodrum figures are in circulation in Uist . His name appears even in proverbs such as
’ S duilighe dhomhsa me throtan na do MhacCodrum a theann réis .
The authenticity of many of the stories is open to grave doubts ; some sayings are attributed to him now which can be shown to have had no connexion with him in the traditions of previous generations . ( 1 ) The well - known address to the drowned fly which is widely attributed to MacCodrum and commemorated in the proverb Cho cearbach ris a ’ chuileig a chaidh am bainne MhicCodrum ,
seems to belong to this class . The older shennachies

ascribed this witticism to a person known to Uist tradition as An Gille Glas ,
who is identified in Skye — whether rightly or wrongly — with Donald Glas , an ancestor of the MacLeods of Drynoch . A number of other stories current in Uist have been omitted from the text because they come under suspicion on similar grounds . ( Cf . Celtic Monthly , v , 38 . )

IV
According to some accounts the voyage was to Arisaig . Further questions — Có as fear riaghlaidh air a ’ bhàta ?
etc . — are sometimes added , but these and the retorts are also ascribed to others . According to some the exchanges took place between Alexander MacDonald and Duncan Bàn Macintyre when the latter was on one occasion coming off a boat at Tigh a ’ Chreagain , Loch Aweside . Another and better - known version says that the replies were given to Macintyre by a young lad who ferried him across Kyle Rea during a tour made by him for the purpose of collecting names for his book ( MT . , xii , No . 22 ; Celtic Monthly , ii , 222 ) .
Uachdar is a township in Benbecula beside the North Ford and opposite Carinish . Perhaps this should be told as two separate incidents .

Some verses by Alexander MacDonald , the catechist , appear in UB . John Lanne Buchanan describes the order of catechists ( whom he calls “ questars ” ) . The following apparently refers to Alexander MacDonald : “ There is a blind bully of this order [of questars] in Uist , who , in order to escape contempt , and secure respectful attention both to his person and his doctrines , carries about with him , wherever he goes , loaded pistols . As he is remarkably strong , as well as full of courage , though blind , few people are fond of grappling with him ” ( John Lanne Buchanan , Travels in the Western Hebrides , 244 ) .

2942 . Ma - ruibhe :
Máel Ruba ( 640 - 722 ) , who is invoked here , was abbot of Bangor in Ulster , but spent the latter part of his life in Scotland , founding the monastery of Applecross in 673 . His name is frequently used for purposes of asseveration in Uist ( Celtic Place - Names of Scotland , 287 ) .

This is the best remembered of all MacCodrum ’ s sayings . Loch Hasten is a small loch — much larger before it was drained — near the rock of the same name
( Creag Hàstan )
to the west of Loch Sandary . Unlike Loch Sandary , which was drained by the Abhainn Mhór into Ceann a ’ Bhàigh ,
Loch Hasten was drained towards the west .

In this story MacCodrum appears as a practical joker rather than as a wit . Whether this was a frequent rôle with him is hard to say . Another story would seem to show that it was , but it is not well authenticated , and has , in view of its improbability ( reminiscent rather of the exploits of MacCrùislig or Gill - easbuig Aotrom than of MacCodrum ) , been excluded from the text . It represents him as going to a cemetery situated on an island ( ? Vallay ) to which a funeral was about to take place , putting off his clothes , and lying among the graves before anyone else arrived . The first to appear on the scene were two men who had charge of the whisky . On seeing them , he who lay among the graves suddenly stood up . The two men , after recovering somewhat from their fright , decided to offer a dram to the apparition . This was accepted , and so was a second , but the third was refused with the ambiguous remark , “ Tha gu leòr eile a ’ tighinn a so as mo dheaghaidh , agus fàgaidh mi an còrr acasan . ”

The name of one of the persons in this story should perhaps be written with a surname — Iain MacGille - Chrìosd .
There are Clann Mhic Gille - Chrìosd still in North Uist , but they now pass officially as Macleans .

Patrick Nicolson was a native of Skye who came to Uist about the middle of the eighteenth century . He was a merchant in Benbecula , and in course of time ( probably after MacCodrum ’ s death ) became factor for Clanranald and tacksman of Torlum and Griminish , for which he paid , according to the Clan Ranald Rental of 1798 , an annual rent of £100 Scots . John Lanne Buchanan has the following notice of him : “ … Mr Patrick Nicholson , an industrious farmer and enterprizing merchant . Mr Nicholson , in his commerce with mankind , is as just and upright as any man in his line of life , and in a quarter so distant from the seats of law and government , can well be supposed to be . He is a great encourager of the industrious poor ; and , though not a native of the place , is highly and justly esteemed by all ranks of people ” ( MC . , xlix ; Fraser - Mackintosh , Antiquarian Notes , Second Series , 312 - 313 ; John Lanne Buchanan , Travels in the Western Hebrides , 40 ) .

2968 . The reference is to the fact that the Nicolsons were known as Clann Mhic Neacail a ’ bhrochain .
Cf . the following sayings :

Brochan Chlann Mhic Neacail
Tog ’ n ad uchd e ;
Lite Chlann Mhic Neacail
Tog air sop e .

Clann Mhic Neacail a ’ bhrochain
’ S an droch aran eòrna ,
Nam potagan mine
’ S nan craigeanan feòla .
( Cf . Trans . Gael . Soc . Invss . , xxix , 337 . )
